01f49d73-e8a1-4f23-be30-d01bd52f89a2.name: Hippocampal formation as a hierarchical generative model
01f49d73-e8a1-4f23-be30-d01bd52f89a2.description:
This is a computational model that casts the hippocampal formation as a hierarchical generative model that organizes sequential experiences, such as such as rodent trajectories during spatial navigation, into coherent spatiotemporal contexts. The model addresses the formation of spatial maps (in the hippocampus) and the the offline resampling of fictive sequences from the generative model (aka generative replay) for the sake of continual learning of multiple sequential experiences. It reproduces several empirical findings on internally generated hippocampal sequences (e.g., replays). It can also be used to analyze the spatial codes that emerge in the hippocampus during spatial learning; and replay dynamics. 

The computational model is described in the preprint publication P2331: Stoianov I., Maisto D., Pezzulo G., (2020) The hippocampal formation as a hierarchical generative model supporting generative replay and continual learning. BiorXiv preprint (https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.01.16.908889v1.full)

082bb2b5-a171-471b-b2f8-38c8248a0ea6.name: 2D Primary Visual Cortex Mean-Field Model
082bb2b5-a171-471b-b2f8-38c8248a0ea6.description:
Using voltage-sensitive dye imaging (VSDI), [Muller et al. (2014)](http://doi.org/10.1038/ncomms4675) showed that the stimulus-evoked population response in the primary visual cortex of the awake monkey performing visual tasks propagates as a travelling wave, with consistent dynamics across trials. [Chemla et al. (2019)](https://doi.org/10.1523/JNEUROSCI.2792-18.2019) further showed that these propagating waves are suppressive and suggested that their role is to increase the acuity of the visual system when presented with ambiguous stimuli.

This theoretical model accounts for the aforementioned phenomena. While a detailed model of a neocortical column has been published ([Markram et al. (2015)](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cell.2015.09.029)), its computational cost does not allow its generalization to a 12 cm2 spatial scale. The present model uses a mean-field formalism derived from networks of spiking neurons (adaptive exponential and fire AdEx model). Under this approach, proposed by [El Boustani and Destexhe (2009)](http://dx.doi.org/10.1162/neco.2009.02-08-710), the evolution of interconnected populations of neurons are described. Previous work allowed for the construction of 1-dimensional mean-field ring models ([Zerlaut et al. (2018)](https://doi.org/10.1007/s10827-017-0668-2), [di Volo et al. (2019)](http://dx.doi.org/10.1162/neco_a_01173)). Indeed, the ring geometry offers a simple framework to investigate the emergence of spatio-temporal patterns of activity ([Hansel and Sompolinsky (1995)](https://doi.org/10.1007/BF00158335)). The present implementation extends these models: a network of two cortical excitatory and inhibitory neuron populations, connected with physiological connectivity profiles, is spatially arranged in a 2-dimensional geometry. The stimulus-evoked response of the model is computed under mean-field formalism.

08a973a3-465e-4b21-a108-7909e2d0c368.name: Mean-field approximation of network of biophysical neurons driven by conductance-based ion exchange
08a973a3-465e-4b21-a108-7909e2d0c368.description:
We derived a ‘next-generation’ neural mass model [1] describing the mean field activity of a neuronal population driven by ion exchange mechanisms. The model is derived as the mathematical limit of an infinite number of all-to-all coupled Hodgkin-Huxley-type neurons [2], as in [3].

This establishes a link between the biophysical description at the cellular scale and the dynamics observable at the mesoscopic scale. Experimental co-recordings of extracellular local field potential and extracellular [K+] show the correlation between pathological bursting and extra-cellular [K+] elevation. Such dynamics is captured by our model, which can also reproduce an extensive repertoire of behaviors including multi-stability during simulated healthy states, pathological spiking, bursting, and depolarization block. This model could serve as a computational baseline to address core questions in epilepsy research, studying the influence of changes in extracellular ionic conditions on whole brain dynamics in health and disease. A first implementation connecting neural mass models into The Virtual Brain shows that a local elevation of potassium bath concentration in a brain region can lead to the propagation of pathological activities across the whole network.

[1] Bandyopadhyay, A., Rabuffo, G., Calabrese, C., Gudibanda, K., Depannemaecker, D., Ivanov, A., ... & Petkoski, S. (2021). Mean-field approximation of network of biophysical neurons driven by conductance-based ion exchange. bioRxiv, 2021-10.

[2] Depannemaecker, D., Ivanov, A., Lillo, D., Spek, L., Bernard, C., & Jirsa, V. (2022). A unified physiological framework of transitions between seizures, sustained ictal activity and depolarization block at the single neuron level. Journal of computational neuroscience, 1-17.

[3] Montbrió, E., Pazó, D., & Roxin, A. (2015). Macroscopic description for networks of spiking neurons. Physical Review X, 5(2), 021028.
 
**Usage instructions**
 
The model is distributed as part of the [main TVB codebase](https://github.com/the-virtual-brain/tvb-root). 

For detailed instructions on how to use the model please refer to this [demo notebook](https://github.com/the-virtual-brain/tvb-root/blob/master/tvb_documentation/demos/exploring_K_ION_Exchange_model.ipynb).
This is the first release.

09825984-730b-42c7-b53c-0d2346149e86.name: Bayesian Virtual Epileptic Patient
09825984-730b-42c7-b53c-0d2346149e86.description:
The Bayesian Virtual Epileptic Patient is a probabilistic framework designed to infer the spatial map of epileptogenicity in a personalized large-scale brain model of epilepsy spread. 
BVEP relies on the personalized structural data, and we use the recently developed algorithms No-U-Turn Sampler (NUTS) and Automatic Differentiation Variational Inference (ADVI). 
These accurately estimate the degree of epileptogenicity of brain regions, which is responsible for the seizure initiation and propagation.
Тhe convergence diagnostics and posterior behavior analysis validate the reliability of the estimations.
The Bayesian framework used in this work proposes an appropriate patient-specific strategy for estimating the epileptogenicity of the brain regions to improve outcome after epilepsy surgery.
Bayesian Virtual Epileptic Patient (BVEP) to invert a individualized whole-brain model of epilepsy spread by PPLs using No-U-Turn Sampler (NUTS) and Automatic Differentiation Variational Inference (ADVI).

Installation:

For simulation using TVB:

[https://www.thevirtualbrain.org/tvb/zwei](https://www.thevirtualbrain.org/tvb/zwei)

For inference using Stan:

[https://mc-stan.org/](https://mc-stan.org/)

For inference using PyMC3:

[https://docs.pymc.io/](https://docs.pymc.io/)

09cbcd03-1e39-497a-a34e-090dde3617d8.name: Basal ganglia network model
09cbcd03-1e39-497a-a34e-090dde3617d8.description:
Shreyas M. Suryanarayana, Jeanette Hellgren Kotaleski, Sten Grillner, Kevin N. Gurney,
Roles for globus pallidus externa revealed in a computational model of action selection in the basal ganglia,
Neural Networks,
Volume 109,
2019,
Pages 113-136,
ISSN 0893-6080,
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neunet.2018.10.003.
(http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0893608018302880)

Abstract: The basal ganglia are considered vital to action selection - a hypothesis supported by several biologically plausible computational models. Of the several subnuclei of the basal ganglia, the globus pallidus externa (GPe) has been thought of largely as a relay nucleus, and its intrinsic connectivity has not been incorporated in significant detail, in any model thus far. Here, we incorporate newly revealed subgroups of neurons within the GPe into an existing computational model of the basal ganglia, and investigate their role in action selection. Three main results ensued. First, using previously used metrics for selection, the new extended connectivity improved the action selection performance of the model. Second, low frequency theta oscillations were observed in the subpopulation of the GPe (the TA or ‘arkypallidal’ neurons) which project exclusively to the striatum. These oscillations were suppressed by increased dopamine activity — revealing a possible link with symptoms of Parkinson’s disease. Third, a new phenomenon was observed in which the usual monotonic relationship between input to the basal ganglia and its output within an action ‘channel’ was, under some circumstances, reversed. Thus, at high levels of input, further increase of this input to the channel could cause an increase of the corresponding output rather than the more usually observed decrease. Moreover, this phenomenon was associated with the prevention of multiple channel selection, thereby assisting in optimal action selection. Examination of the mechanistic origin of our results showed the so-called ‘prototypical’ GPe neurons to be the principal subpopulation influencing action selection. They control the striatum via the arkypallidal neurons and are also able to regulate the output nuclei directly. Taken together, our results highlight the role of the GPe as a major control hub of the basal ganglia, and provide a mechanistic account for its control function.

Keywords: Action selection; Network models; Globus pallidus externa; Arkypallidal GPe neurons; Prototypical GPe neurons

0b464928-c90b-4800-941a-71d1e3a62f1f.name: Multiscale model of a spiking basal ganglia network and a whole-brain mean-field model with The Virtual Brain
0b464928-c90b-4800-941a-71d1e3a62f1f.description:
Deep brain stimulation (DBS) has been successfully applied in various neurodegenerative diseases as an effective symptomatic treatment. However, its mechanisms of action within the brain network are still poorly understood. For an accurate prediction of the effects of DBS, we implement a detailed spiking model of the basal ganglia, which we combine with The Virtual Brain via our previously developed co-simulation environment. This multiscale co-simulation approach builds on the extensive previous literature of spiking models of the basal ganglia while simultaneously offering a whole-brain perspective on widespread effects of the stimulation going beyond the motor circuit. In the first demonstration of our model, we show that virtual DBS can move the firing rates of a Parkinson’s disease patient’s thalamus - basal ganglia network towards the healthy regime while, at the same time, altering the activity in distributed cortical regions with a pronounced effect in frontal regions. The developed modeling approach has the potential to optimize DBS lead placement and configuration and forecast the success of DBS treatment for individual patients.
All of the information necessary to re-run the analysis in the analysis of Meier et al. (2022) is provided in [this manual](https://github.com/the-virtual-brain/tvb-multiscale/blob/Meier_etal_ExpNeur2022/Reproducing_results_of_Meier_et_al_2022.docx.pdf)

0f752e56-d2fd-42c3-b211-93c816cda289.name: Bona fide models of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in different physiologically relevant states
0f752e56-d2fd-42c3-b211-93c816cda289.description:
To develop bona fide atomistic models of nAChRs in their different physiological states, i.e. resting, active and desensitized, the followin initial coordinates from cryo-EM were used:

**nAChR α7**:
- [PDB:7KOO]: nAChR α7 in the resting state bound to α-bungarotoxin (chains F-J) and calcium ions (residue name CAL)
- [PDB:7KOQ]: nAChR α7 in the desensitized state bound to epibatidine (residue name EPJ) and calcium ions (residue name CAL) 

**nAChR α4β2:**
- [PDB:6CNJ]: nAChR α4β2 in the 2α:3β stoichiometry in the desensitized state bound to nicotine (residue name NCT) and in presence cholesterol (residue name CHL1) in the transmembrane domain

**nAChR α3β4:**
- [PDB:6PV8]: nAChR α3β4 in the desensitized state bound to AT-1001 (residue name P1M) and in presence of cholesterol (residue name CHL1) in the transmembrane domain

**nAChR muscle-type:**
- [PDB:6UWZ]: nAChR muscle-type in resting state bound to α-bungarotoxin (chains F and G)

All protein structures above were embedded in a membrane composed of 1-palmitoyl-2-oleoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine (POPC) bilayer, put in a solvation box containing water (TIP3P model) and a physiological concentration (0.15 M) of NaCl (residue names Sod and CLA). The molecular systems were relaxed by a hundred nanoseconds of all-atom Molecular Dynamics (MD) at room temperature and 1 bar pressure using the CHARMM36m force field. The most populated cluster was extracted from the MD trajectory and considered as the (statistically) relevant configuration for the physiological state.

For each cluster center, we provide Cartesian coordinates of the protein with ligands and the full system including the solvent and the membrane.

0ffae3c2-443c-44fd-919f-70a4b01506a4.name: Mouse CA1 pyramidal neuron model, morphology mpg150211_A_idA
0ffae3c2-443c-44fd-919f-70a4b01506a4.description:
This model is part of a collection of ten distinct single-cell computational models of mouse CA1 pyramidal neurons, created using a well-established computational workflow, and ready to be used in a full-scale hippocampal circuit. This data-driven model is based on a 3D reconstruction of a biocytin-stained cell morphology using Neurolucida and on electrophysiological features extracted from data collected from mice by patch-clamp, and implemented using the BluePyOpt algorithm.
This version of the model is the one used in Vitale et al. (2023) [doi:10.3389/fncel.2023.1281932](https://doi.org/10.3389/fncel.2023.1281932)

101136f1-28ac-4e54-9823-53155709de3c.name: Regulation of adenylyl cyclase 5 in striatal neurons
101136f1-28ac-4e54-9823-53155709de3c.description:
Models reported in the paper:

Regulation of adenylyl cyclase 5 in striatal neurons confers the ability to detect coincident neuromodulatory signals
 
Neil J. Bruce, Daniele Narzi, Daniel Trpevski, Siri Camee van Keulen, Anu G. Nair, Ursula Röthlisberger, Rebecca C. Wade, Paolo Carloni, Jeanette Hellgren Kotaleski

PLOS Computational Biology (2019)

109e6b5f-589f-4198-a053-7361b0af5ec5.name: Model of excitable dendrites
109e6b5f-589f-4198-a053-7361b0af5ec5.description:
Many neurons possess dendrites enriched with sodium channels and are capable of generating action potentials. However, the role of dendritic sodium spikes remain unclear. Here, we study computational models of neurons to investigate the
functional effects of dendritic spikes. In agreement with previous studies, we found that point neurons or neurons with passive dendrites increase their somatic firing rate in response to the correlation of synaptic bombardment for a wide range of
input conditions, i.e. input firing rates, synaptic conductances, or refractory periods. However, neurons with active dendrites show the opposite behavior: for a wide range of conditions the firing rate decreases as a function of correlation. We found this property in three types of models of dendritic excitability: a Hodgkin-Huxley model of dendritic spikes, a model with integrate and fire dendrites, and a discrete-state dendritic model. We conclude that fast dendritic spikes confer much broader computational properties to neurons, sometimes opposite to that of point neurons.

The results of model simulations were published in:
Górski, Tomasz, et al. "Dendritic sodium spikes endow neurons with inverse firing rate response to correlated synaptic activity." Journal of computational neuroscience 45.3 (2018): 223-234. [doi:10.1007/s10827-018-0707-7](https://doi.org/10.1007/s10827-018-0707-7)

1160fca0-1565-4a09-b79b-c19aa5776e23.name: Granule cell 2011 for studying GoC-GrC circuit (GrC2011Souza)
1160fca0-1565-4a09-b79b-c19aa5776e23.description: Souza & De Schutter 2011 model of GranuleCell (GrC) and published in 10.1186/2042-1001-1-7 This is a single compartment model; it is a modification of Diwakar et al. 2009 multicompartment model (GrC2009Diwakar). It was used as the component for GrC in the network the authors constructed. This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model in modelDB accession 139656. Code to Model template for GrC2011Souza This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model for CerebUnit. To run this model: from executive import ExecutiveControl as ec desired_model = ec.choose_model( modelscale = "cells", modelname = "GrC2011Souza" ) Model description in ModelDB #139656 . ... Previous one-dimensional network modeling of the cerebellar granular layer has been successfully linked with a range of cerebellar cortex oscillations observed in vivo. However, the recent discovery of gap junctions between Golgi cells (GoCs), which may cause oscillations by themselves, has raised the question of how gap-junction coupling affects GoC and granular-layer oscillations. To investigate this question, we developed a novel two-dimensional computational model of the GoC-granule cell (GC) circuit with and without gap junctions between GoCs. ... Note that, GrC2011Souza is the granule cell used in the overall model of the GoC-GrC circuit. This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model for CerebUnit.

12564edc-2199-421b-85f2-aa954250b35a.name: Granule cell 2019 - Regular firing
12564edc-2199-421b-85f2-aa954250b35a.description:
Granule Cell 2019 - Regular firing model. Typical regular response to a steady current injection

To correctly simulate it: 
1) Temperature = 32°
2) Vinit (Vm) = -70
3) Currents injection used in the paper = 10, 16 and 22pA
4) Currents injection, 100ms delay, 2000ms injection and 2000ms tstop (length of the simulation)
Parameter tuning differentiates granule cell subtypes enriching the repertoire of retransmission properties at the cerebellum input stage.
Stefano Masoli, Marialuisa Tognolina, Umberto Laforenza, Francesco Moccia, Egidio D’Angelo
bioRxiv 638247; doi: https://doi.org/10.1101/638247

13b37dd4-37db-4047-99d6-9ccdf014eb67.name: Purkinje cell 2018 for studying voltage and branch specific climbing fiber effects (PC2018Zang)
13b37dd4-37db-4047-99d6-9ccdf014eb67.description: Zang et al. 2018 model of PurkinjeCell (PC) and published in 10.1016/j.celrep.2018.07.011 This is a multi-compartment modified version of the Purkinje cell from Mike Hausser (cell 2, 19.2.97, PC1997aHausser). This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model in modelDB accession 243446. Code to Model template for PC2018Zang This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model for CerebUnit. To run this model: from executive import ExecutiveControl as ec desired_model = ec.choose_model( modelscale = "cells", modelname = "PC2018Zang" ) Model description in ModelDB #243446 Climbing fibers (CFs) provide instructive signals driving cerebellar learning, but mechanisms causing the variable CF responses in Purkinje cells (PCs) are not fully understood. Using a new experimentally validated PC model, we unveil the ionic mechanisms underlying CF-evoked distinct spike waveforms on different parts of the PC. We demonstrate that voltage can gate both the amplitude and the spatial range of CF-evoked Ca2+ influx by the availability of K+ currents. ... The voltage- and branch-specific CF responses can increase dendritic computational capacity and enable PCs to actively integrate CF signals. This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model for CerebUnit.

154db7b4-508f-41cc-90b6-645abaf7a6e3.name: The Virtual Aging Brain
154db7b4-508f-41cc-90b6-645abaf7a6e3.description:
The Virtual Ageing Brain is a mechanistic model linking changes in structural connectivity and brain function to address the inter-individual variability in decline of cognitive abilities during healthy ageing. At the core of the VAB is a dynamical brain network model informed by individual brain imaging data (structural whole-brain connectivity), and a connectivity mask selecting interhemispheric connections is used to define the age-related changes to the structure. This model can be then used to generate synthetic resting state fMRI data, and employed to create virtually aged data for an individual, or in an inference loop to estimate the model parameters.

The individual models were constructed using the structural connectivity matrices of the [1000BRAINS](https://search.kg.ebrains.eu/instances/83407c06-b494-4307-861e-d06a5aecdf8a) dataset.

**Installation**
For installation instructions please follow the [`README.md`](https://github.com/ins-amu/virtual_aging_brain/tree/v1.0.0#readme).

**Instructions to run the model**
To run the simulations, please follow the [`notebooks
/02_vab_github_simulation_virtual_aging.ipynb`](https://github.com/ins-amu/virtual_aging_brain/blob/v1.0.0/notebooks/02_vab_github_simulation_virtual_aging.ipynb).
This is the first release of the model.

174482dd-fa26-4a1b-a38e-4c57bd67e384.name: Large-scale high-resolution cortical model with long-range interconnections
174482dd-fa26-4a1b-a38e-4c57bd67e384.description:
Large-scale cortical model (several square centimeters of cortex) at biological neural and synaptic densities able to express both slow-waves and asynchronous awake states. The model is based on a bi-dimensional grid of neural populations, interconnected by long-range synaptic connectivity, which reflects the modular organization of the cortex.

Two implementations of the model are available. From one side, a NEST version of the model is distributed, in order to make it available to the large scientific community. At the same time, the model was also implemented using the proprietary mixed time and event driven DPSNN (Distributed Simulator of Plastic Spiking Neural Networks) simulator. In this natively distributed and parallel engine, the full neural system is represented by a network of C++ processes equipped with a communication infrastructure that can be easily interfaced with both Message Passing Interface (MPI) and custom software/hardware communication systems.

The simulations of different dynamical brain states constitute a challenge for parallel simulation of large multi-scale models of the brain. In DPSNN, efficient simulations resulted from the optimization of both the computational power and the inter-process communications. For this reason, speed-up measures as well as strong and weak scaling analysis was performed on the model simulated on DPSNN (Pastorelli et al, 2019).

We explored networks up to 192×192 modules, each composed of 1,250 integrate-and-fire neurons with spike-frequency adaptation, and exponentially decaying inter-modular synaptic connectivity with varying spatial decay constant. For the largest networks the total number of simulated synapses was over 70 billion.

Reference:
Pastorelli E, Capone C, Simula F, Sanchez-Vives MV, Del Giudice P, Mattia M and Paolucci PS (2019) Scaling of a Large-Scale Simulation of Synchronous Slow-Wave and Asynchronous Awake-Like Activity of a Cortical Model With Long-Range Interconnections. Front. Syst. Neurosci. 13:33. doi: 10.3389/fnsys.2019.00033

1b72e1e4-8061-46d2-89af-e5d24dff9340.name: Granule cell 2009 modeling Na+ channels to ensure fast spiking and back-propagation (GrC2009Diwakar)
1b72e1e4-8061-46d2-89af-e5d24dff9340.description: Diwakar et al. 2009 model of GranuleCell (GrC) and published in 10.1152/jn.90382.2008 This is the multi-compartment model. It models the rat granule cells because the model was derived from slices taken from 20 +/- 2 days old rats. This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model in modelDB accession 116835. Code to Model template for GrC2009Diwakar This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model for CerebUnit. To run this model: from executive import ExecutiveControl as ec desired_model = ec.choose_model( modelscale = "cells", modelname = "GrC2009Diwakar" ) Model description in ModelDB #116835 A detailed multicompartmental model was used to study neuronal electroresponsiveness of cerebellar granule cells in rats. Here we show that, in cerebellar granule cells, Na+ channels are enriched in the axon, especially in the hillock, but almost absent from soma and dendrites. Numerical simulations indicated that granule cells have a compact electrotonic structure allowing EPSPs to diffuse with little attenuation from dendrites to axon. The spike arose almost simultaneously along the whole axonal ascending branch and invaded the hillock, whose activation promoted spike back-propagation with marginal delay (<200 micros) and attenuation (<20 mV) into the somato-dendritic compartment. For details check the cited article. This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model.

1ccc23ec-d3a6-43b6-b96f-41e9c4221a15.name: SpiNNCer: Neuromorphic cerebellum implementation on SpiNNaker
1ccc23ec-d3a6-43b6-b96f-41e9c4221a15.description:
This is an implementation for the SpiNNaker neuromorphic system of a large-scale, bio-inspired cerebellum model. The model consists of a network containing 97k neurons and 4.2M synapses. An implementation of the same model for the NEST simulator (using generic computational resources and double precision floating point arithmetic) is also available as a basis for validation.

- [Results from the simulation of this model](https://search.kg.ebrains.eu/instances/Dataset/069e4718-2b4a-4056-9c8f-e646a841b2dd)
- [Full description of the model](https://doi.org/10.3389/fninf.2019.00037)
Small run of SpiNNCer Model with random spikes

21441582-2497-496d-900a-ac5444cffdbf.name: Conductance-based Adaptive Exponential Integrate and Fire Model
21441582-2497-496d-900a-ac5444cffdbf.description:
The intrinsic electrophysiological properties of single neurons can be described by a broad spectrum of models, from the most realistic Hodgkin-Huxley type models with numerous detailed mechanisms to the phenomenological models. The Adaptive Exponential integrate-and-fire (AdEx) model has emerged as a convenient “middle-ground” model. With a low computational cost, but keeping biophysical interpretation of the parameters it has been extensively used for simulation of large neural networks. However, because of its current-based adaptation, it can generate unrealistic behaviors. We show the limitations of the AdEx model, and to avoid them, we introduce the Conductance-based Adaptive Exponential integrate-and-fire model (CAdEx). We give an analysis of the dynamic of the CAdEx model and we show the variety of firing patterns that it can produce. We propose the CAdEx model as a richer alternative to perform network simulations with simplified models reproducing neuronal intrinsic properties.

Here is a implementation of CAdEx model using Brian2 neuronal simulator and Python language.

22eaa57b-d94f-4308-bd8f-602fc48631f7.name: A multiarea multiscale model with dopamine depletion in basal ganglia and cerebellum predicts changes in thalamocortical beta oscillations
22eaa57b-d94f-4308-bd8f-602fc48631f7.description:
A multiarea multiscale model (spiking neural networks and mass models) of cortex, thalamus, cerebellum, and basal ganglia. The model can be simulated to obtain both physiological conditions and different levels of Parkinsonism (i.e., dopamine depletion).

#### Required packages

- Python 3.8
- [NEST simulator 2.20.2](https://zenodo.org/records/5242954)
- [fooof](https://pypi.org/project/fooof/)
- cerebnest ([branch nest2.20.2_python3.8](https://github.com/marcobiasizzo/cereb-nest/tree/nest2.20.2_python3.8))
- [bgmodel](https://github.com/marcobiasizzo/bgmodel)
 
#### Repository Structure

- PD\_BG\_Cereb\_loop.zip : code to replicate experiment
    - BGs\_nest/: contains BG model definition and script to run it separately
    - Cereb\_nest/: contains cerebellar model definition and script to run it separately
    - nest\_multiscale/: contains code implementing mass model and communication between all areas
    - experiment.py: function to perform EBCC
    - genetic\_algorithm.py: script for optimization
    - main.py: run single multiarea model simulation
    - run\_script.py: runs multiple times main.py
- supplementary.pdf : document containing information about parameters of the SNN models.

#### Run simulation

- Run `main.py` to perform a simulation
- Run `run_script.py` to perform multiple times `main.py`

Simulation data will be automatically saved in savings or share\_results.

To define your simulation, firstly edit the "user parameters" at the beginning of the main script. Other useful parameters can be found in the main file, while model parameters are set in the population repository.
This updated version includes a Jupyter notebook, "generate_figures.ipynb", to reproduce the figures from Gambosi et al. (2024).

2314761d-efab-40f6-962c-b65e8a344ed0.name: Modelled adenylyl cyclase isoform structures
2314761d-efab-40f6-962c-b65e8a344ed0.description:
Model presents a comparative electrostatic analysis of the catalytic domains of all nine
transmembrane adenylyl cyclase, AC, isoforms.

Model was  reported:

Rudi Tong, Rebecca C Wade, Neil J Bruce
Comparative electrostatic analysis of adenylyl cyclase for isoform dependent regulation properties

Proteins. (2016) 84(12):1844-1858  and
Proteins. (2019) 87(7) 619-620 (corrections to Fig.5 and 7)

237fc014-010f-447b-b070-4b00848a513a.name: Purkinje cell 2006 for studying resurgent Na+ current and Kv3 channel interactions on rate of spontaneous firing (PC2006Akemann)
237fc014-010f-447b-b070-4b00848a513a.description: Akemann & Knöpfel 2006 model of PurkinjeCell (PC) and published in 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.5204-05.2006 This is a single compartment model. This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model in modelDB accession 80769. Code to Model template for PC2006Akemann This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model for CerebUnit. To run this model: from executive import ExecutiveControl as ec desired_model = ec.choose_model( modelscale = "cells", modelname = "PC2006Akemann" ) Model description in ModelDB #80769 Purkinje neurons spontaneously generate action potentials in the absence of synaptic drive and thereby exert a tonic, yet plastic, input to their target cells in the deep cerebellar nuclei. Purkinje neurons express two ionic currents with biophysical properties that are specialized for high-frequency firing: resurgent sodium currents and potassium currents mediated by Kv3.3. Numerical simulations indicated that Kv3.3 increases the spontaneous firing rate via cooperation with resurgent sodium currents. We conclude that the rate of spontaneous action potential firing of Purkinje neurons is controlled by the interaction of Kv3.3 potassium currents and resurgent sodium currents. See paper for more and details. This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model for CerebUnit.

26305a02-fd34-4d75-ab8e-4c9f8e62b693.name: Olfactory bulb mitral cell model
26305a02-fd34-4d75-ab8e-4c9f8e62b693.description:
This is a conversion to NEURON of the mitral cell model described in: 

Bhalla US and Bower JM. (1993) Exploring parameter space in detailed single
neuron models: simulations of the mitral and granule cells of the olfactory bulb. 
J. Neurophysiol. 69:1948-1965. 

The original model was written in GENESIS and was downloaded from:
http://www.bbb.caltech.edu/BABEL/babeldirs/cells/mitral_granule/
This version adds a SciUnit wrapper to facilitate validation of the model with respect to experimental data.

298da091-5ffb-41db-9581-e26832124aa5.name: Macroscopic model of brain function
298da091-5ffb-41db-9581-e26832124aa5.description:
This work, co-supervised in Destexhe and Jirsa groups, aims at connecting empirical knowledge across scales from microscopic (nanometers to micrometers—molecules to whole neurons) to macroscopic brain activity (centimeters to meters—brain areas to individual subjects' brains) with theoretical tools (Goldman et al. 2019). Not unlike how microscopic interactions between molecules underlie structures formed in macroscopic states of matter, using statistical physics, the dynamics of microscopic neural phenomena can be linked to macroscopic brain dynamics through mesoscopic scales. While statistical physics has been utile to describe the patterns of pair-wise and population-wide correlations at the microscopic scale in brain research (Nghiem, Telenczuk, et al. 2018; Schneidman et al. 2006) such tools have not yet been employed to formally bridge from microscopic to macroscopic scales. 

Here, methods for the macroscopic quantification of neural activity are introduced (Equations 1 and 2, Fig.1) and used to quantify global brain dynamics in states spanning deep sleep to resting and active wakefulness. In essence, spectral energy (U; equation 1) is defined as the integral under the Fourier power spectrum and the spectral entropy (H; equation 2) is defined as the log of the empirical probability distribution of frequencies (P(f)). These measures are made from each subject and each sensor in short time epochs, acknowledging that brain activity is constantly in flux. In magnetoencephalography (MEG) signals from healthy human subjects in resting (Fig.2A top) and active (Fig.2A bottom) states, effective energy and entropy measurements were made from power spectra (Fig.2B) for each epoch. Plotting the energy and entropy for each epoch from one subject, a robust linear relationship between the spectral energy and entropy is apparent (Fig.2C). Histograms show a shift of entropy to higher values and a shift of energy to lower values during active waking compared to resting wakefulness.  

Examining the mean effective energy and entropy for each subject, it is clear that entropy robustly increases (Fig.2D) whereas energy robustly decreases (Fig.2E) during active waking compared to rest. Further, this conserved relationship between mean effective energy and entropy is also observed in electroencephalography data from subjects ranging from deep sleep to wake (Fig.2F). To test whether increased coupling between the system’s components and therefore synchrony could account for the higher energy and lower entropy during less active brain states, coupling was systematically varied in a network of coupled Kuramoto oscillators. Indeed, enhanced coupling can result in lower entropy, higher energy signals (Fig.3). The results indicate that macroscopically observed high synchrony, low complexity brain signals recorded during unconscious states may be accounted for by an increased coupling in the system's components, behaving more like a solid (Peyrache et al. 2012; Le Van Quyen et al. 2016; Olcese et al. 2016; Nghiem, Lina, et al. 2018). In contrast, conscious brain states may be described as less ordered, higher complexity (Sitt et al. 2014; Engemann et al. 2018; Nghiem, Lina, et al. 2018), more liquid-like. 

Next, we sought to determine whether phenomenological changes in microscopic coupling can be biophysically described by known differences in neuromodulation between brain states, and whether microscopic effects of neuromodulation can account for global differences in macroscopic brain dynamics. To this end, mean-field approximations describing populations of excitatory and inhibitory networks (El Boustani and Destexhe 2009; Volo et al. 2019) were connected based on diffusion tractography from human brains to be incorporated as nodes in TVB (Sanz-Leon et al. 2015), thus generating whole human brain simulations (Fig.4). Full brain TVB-AdEX models display spontaneous dynamics sensitive to the effects of neuromodulation, with low entropy, high energy states resulting from increased excitatory spike frequency adaptation resulting from decreased neuromodulation, as is the case in unconscious brain states. Conversely, TVB-AdEX models display spontaneous dynamics that are high entropy and low energy, similar to conscious brain states, when excitatory spike frequency adaptation is low, as is the case due to the enhancement of neuromodulatory signaling during waking and especially attentive brain states.

![Figure 1](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_64bf8536ad8b4872a4121f909be7e82f/DestexheTeam/Goldman/Fig1_GoldmanSGA2_300px.jpeg)

**Figure 1**: Quantifying observables in different brain states. A spectral energy measure, U, is introduced for each time epoch from each subject in each brain state (equation 1), calculated as the integral of each power spectrum. Similarly, a spectral entropy measure is defined, for each epoch from each subject in each brain state, where, P(f) describes the relative heights of power spectral frequency bins (equation 2).

![Figure 2](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_64bf8536ad8b4872a4121f909be7e82f/DestexheTeam/Goldman/Fig2_GoldmanSGA2_400px.jpeg)

**Figure 2**: Decreased spectral energy and increased spectral entropy in more active brain states. (A) Magentoencephalography (MEG) signals (X) from human subjects in resting and active states are used to compute (B) power spectra (X) for each subject, state, sensor, and epoch. Spectral energy (Eq.1) and entropy (Eq.2) are calculated from power spectra. (C) Energy and entropy across epochs for one subject in resting and active waking states. Between brain states, a significant shift in energy and entropy (Mann-Whitney U test, p-values reported) can be seen in histograms as well as a change in slope and intercept of the negative linear energy-entropy relation (best fit line shown, Pearson's r reported) as shown in the scatter plot. The inset labeled dS, dU implies a non-tautological relation between effective energy and entropy as measured empirically. Briefly, shifting power spectral offset results in changed energy values with no effect on entropy. Conversely, shuffling spectral energy between modes modulates the effective entropy, but not the energy. Variation of the spectral energy-entropy relation between brain states is robust across subjects. Mean spectral entropy (D) and mean spectral energy (E) are shown in active state against rest (one point per subject, identity line shown). In the resting state, spectral entropy is consistently smaller and energy larger than in the active state (Wilcoxon signed-rank test). Mean values of effective energy and entropy are shown from an independent dataset of electroencephalography, confirming the conservation of energy-entropy relationship across states of sleeping as well as waking (F).

![Figure 3](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_64bf8536ad8b4872a4121f909be7e82f/DestexheTeam/Goldman/Fig3_GoldmanSGA2_400px.jpeg)

**Figure 3**: Coupling modulates spectral energy and entropy. A parameter exploration of the Kuramoto model is performed in order to investigate effects of coupling on effective energy and entropy. Changing coupling strength, K, between oscillators causes a shift in spectral state variables. Increasing coupling robustly enhances the signal magnitude (A-D), captured by increased spectral energy (E) and diminishes signal complexity (A-D), quantified as diminished spectral entropy (E).

![](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_64bf8536ad8b4872a4121f909be7e82f/DestexheTeam/Goldman/Fig4_GoldmanSGA2_400px.jpeg)

**Figure 4**: Neuromodulation-induced, microscopic changes in spike-frequency adaptation can account for macroscopic changes in state variables between brain states. Mean-field models of adaptive exponential excitatory and inhibitory neurons (adapted from Volo et al. 2019) represent nodes coupled together based on diffusion MRI tractography (A). Spike-frequency adaptation is increased to model the effects of decreased neuromodulation present during unconscious compared to conscious brain states (B-D). Enhancing excitatory spike frequency adaptation in the TVB-AdEx model results in a transition from small magnitude complex signals characteristic of waking brain states to slow waves characteristic of unconscious brain states.

### References

El Boustani, Sami, and Alain Destexhe. 2009. “A Master Equation Formalism for Macroscopic Modeling of Asynchronous Irregular Activity States.” Neural Computation 21 (1): 46–100.

Engemann, Denis A., Federico Raimondo, Jean-Rémi King, Benjamin Rohaut, Gilles Louppe, Frédéric Faugeras, Jitka Annen, et al. 2018. “Robust EEG-Based Cross-Site and Cross-Protocol Classification of States of Consciousness.” Brain: A Journal of Neurology 141 (11): 3179–92.

Goldman, Jennifer S., Núria Tort-Colet, Matteo di Volo, Eduarda Susin, Jules Bouté, Melissa Dali, Mallory Carlu, Trang-Anh Nghiem, Tomasz Górski, and Alain Destexhe. 2019. “Bridging Single Neuron Dynamics to Global Brain States.” Frontiers in Systems Neuroscience 13 (December): 75.

Le Van Quyen, Michel, Lyle E. Muller 2nd, Bartosz Telenczuk, Eric Halgren, Sydney Cash, Nicholas G. 2baa1df0-badd-4313-b576-a145b5990997.name: Rall Morphology Model for Layer 5 Pyramidal Cells in Mouse V1
2baa1df0-badd-4313-b576-a145b5990997.description:
Neocortical processing of sensory input relies on the specific activation of subpopulations within the cortical network. Though specific circuitry is thought to be the primary mechanism underlying this functional principle, we explore here a putative complementary mechanism: whether diverse biophysical features in single neurons contribute to such differential activation. In a previous study, we reported that, in young mice visual cortex, individual neurons differ not only in their excitability but also in their sensitivities to the properties of the membrane potential fluctuations. In the present work, we analyze how this heterogeneity is translated into diverse input-output properties in the context of low synchrony population dynamics. As expected, we found that individual neurons couple differentially to specific form of presynaptic activity (emulating afferent stimuli of various properties) mostly because of their differences in excitability. However, we also found that the response to proximal dendritic input was controlled by the sensitivity to the speed of the fluctuations (which can be linked to various levels of density of sodium channels and sodium inactivation). Our study thus proposes a novel quantitative insight into the functional impact of biophysical heterogeneity: because of their various firing responses to fluctuations, individual neurons will differentially couple to local network activity.
Version published in Plos Comp Biol

2ea91763-bb0b-4a4f-9a6a-eb4d001afde5.name: Mouse stroke Brain network model
2ea91763-bb0b-4a4f-9a6a-eb4d001afde5.description:
The large-scale Mouse Brain Model for simulating the stroke and rehabilitation allows modeling of the results of the experiment defined in CDP1: calcium analysis for a single mouse in the first and in the fourth week after stroke, compared with its healthy activity.
Experimental calcium data are used in a close loop validation system to model the cortical activity of the mouse. 
The open source tracer dataset of the Allen Institute has been implemented into The Virtual Brain (TVB), thus allowing detailed Structural Connectivity (SC) to be obtained (Melozzi et all 2017). This is then used to build large-scale brain network models for the resting state Functional Connectivity and the predictive value of the tracer data is compared and validated against SC derived from diffusion MRI scans. 

The top-down model systematically exploits the effects of the SC constraints upon network dynamics, and was compared with empirical cortical activation maps in SP1, in healthy, stroke and rehabilitation. The model allows systematic analysis of the structural impact of the stroke and of the recovery. This leads to the best fit for parameters which were in agreement with the experimental results for the structural damage during the stroke and the recovery (petkoski et al, in prep). 
Data analysis and modelling were performed for recordings of one hemisphere of one animal (SP1 data), and further recordings from both hemispheres are expected from 4 more animals.

References:
F. Melozzi, M. M. Woodman, V. K. Jirsa and C. Bernard “The Virtual Mouse Brain: A Computational Neuroinformatics Platform to Study Whole Mouse Brain Dynamics, eNeuro, 2017, 4 (3) ENEURO.0111-17.2017; https://doi.org/10.1523/ENEURO.0111-17.2017
Petkoski S, Allegra L, Pavone F, Jirsa V. Brain network model for mouse stroke and recovery  (in preparation)
Allegra Mascaro L, Falotico E, Petkoski S et al. [in review]
This version contains the Matlab code to reproduce 
the simulated data for the already submitted paper in Frontiers of Systems Neuroscience.

32d9115b-f955-4fd3-acd0-4bfd594593d9.name: [Re] Saccade Generator
32d9115b-f955-4fd3-acd0-4bfd594593d9.description:
Partners within the framework of CDP4 have developed a rate neuron model of the saccade generator (SG) in the reticular formation (RF). The model was implemented by UM partner, which consisted of an implementation in NEST of a model proposed by Gancarz & Grossberg (1998). The SG consists of a horizontal and a vertical component each with two long-lead burst neurons (LLBNs), excitatory burst neurons (EBNs), inhibitory burst neurons (IBNs), and tonic neurons (TNs). Within each component, the two directions (left-right, down-up) interact antagonistically. Additionally, both components share a single omnipause neuron (OPN) which tonically inhibits each EBN as long as no saccade is being initiated. Based on network interactions among these RF neurons, the model reproduces typical neuronal activation profiles (Fig. 1A) observed during saccade generation, realistic saccade trajectories (Fig. 1B), and cell tuning properties (Fig. 1C). This model forms the back-end of a larger architecture of visuo-motor integration, transforming eye-displacement vectors obtained from a previous visual target selection process into motor commands for the eye muscles.

#### Publications
Senden, M., Schuecker, J., Hahne, J., Diesmann, M., and Goebel, R. (2018). [Re] "*[A neural model of the saccade generator in the reticular formation.](https://github.com/ReScience-Archives/Senden-Schuecker-Hahne-Diesmann-Goebel-2018/blob/master/article/senden-schuecker-hahne-diesmann-goebel-2018.pdf)*" ReScience 1, 1.

Kroner, A., Driessens, K., and Goebel, R. (in preparation). "*Visual Attention Modelling with Deep Neural Networks*"

#### Code availability
GitHub repository of ReScience: [https://github.com/ReScience-Archives/Senden-Schuecker-Hahne-Diesmann-Goebel-2018](https://github.com/ReScience-Archives/Senden-Schuecker-Hahne-Diesmann-Goebel-2018).

#### Achieved impact
The saccade generator has been successfully integrated into the neurorobotics platform controling the eye movements of a simulated robot.
The salience prediction autoencoder network has been successfully integrated into the neurorobotics platform is used in a simulated robot able to fixate highly salient targets, recognize the object at its current locus of fixation and store the identity and location of this object in memory


#### Data provider and Affiliation:
images: Tsun-Yi Ling, Cornell NYC Tech and the CornellComputer Science Department
eye-movement heatmaps: Ming Jiang, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, National University of Singapore

#### Source Publication, HBP Task, WP or SP:

Lin, T.-Y., Maire, M., Belongie, S., Hays, J., Perona, P., Ramanan, D., . . .
Zitnick, C. L. (2014). Microsoft coco: Common objects in context. In
European conference on computer vision (pp. 740–755).

nition (cvpr) (pp. 1072–1080).

### Use of the data in the modelling process: 
These data were used for the training as well as testing of the saliency autoencoder."

32e21f84-03e6-442c-ab0c-e115aa89dec7.name: Purkinje cell 2015 for studying alcohol modulation on 1088 compartment model (PC2015aForrest)
32e21f84-03e6-442c-ab0c-e115aa89dec7.description:
Forrest 2015 model of PurkinjeCell (PC) and published in 10.1186/s12868-015-0162-6 This is a multi-compartment (1088) model. This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model in modelDB accession 180789. Code to Model template for PC2015aForrest This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model for CerebUnit. To run this model: from executive import ExecutiveControl as ec desired_model = ec.choose_model( modelscale = "cells", modelname = "PC2015aForrest" ) Model description in ModelDB #180789 ... we employ a novel reduction algorithm to produce a 2 compartment model of the cerebellar Purkinje neuron from a previously published, 1089 compartment model. It runs more than 400 times faster and retains the electrical behavior of the full model. So, it is more suitable for inclusion in large network models, where computational power is a limiting issue. We show the utility of this reduced model by demonstrating that it can replicate the full model’s response to alcohol, which can in turn reproduce experimental recordings from Purkinje neurons following alcohol application. ... Note:
  • PC2015aForrest has 1088 compartment
  • PC2015bForrest is the reduced version of PC2015aForrest with two compartments
This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model.

34f3ff1a-4965-4ab6-9a35-19ef7c24ccb9.name: Motor control model - T443
34f3ff1a-4965-4ab6-9a35-19ef7c24ccb9.description:
A model of the basal ganglia system was presented in Lindahl M, Hellgren Kotaleski J. (2017) Untangling Basal Ganglia Network Dynamics and Function: Role of Dopamine Depletion and Inhibition Investigated in a Spiking Network Model. eNeuro. 2017 Jan 12;3(6). pii: ENEURO.0156-16.2016. [doi: 10.1523/ENEURO.0156-16.2016](https://doi.org/10.1523/ENEURO.0156-16.2016).

The basal ganglia are a crucial brain system for behavioral selection, and their function is disturbed in Parkinson's disease (PD), where neurons exhibit inappropriate synchronization and oscillations. We present a spiking neural model of basal ganglia including plausible details on synaptic dynamics, connectivity patterns, neuron behavior, and dopamine effects. Recordings of neuronal activity in the subthalamic nucleus and Type A (TA; arkypallidal) and Type I (TI; prototypical) neurons in globus pallidus externa were used to validate the model. Simulation experiments predict that both local inhibition in striatum and the existence of an indirect pathway are important for basal ganglia to function properly over a large range of cortical drives. The dopamine depletion-induced increase of AMPA efficacy in corticostriatal synapses to medium spiny neurons (MSNs) with dopamine receptor D2 synapses (CTX-MSN D2) and the reduction of MSN lateral connectivity (MSN-MSN) were found to contribute significantly to the enhanced synchrony and oscillations seen in PD. Additionally, reversing the dopamine depletion-induced changes to CTX-MSN D1, CTX-MSN D2, TA-MSN, and MSN-MSN couplings could improve or restore basal ganglia action selection ability. In summary, we found multiple changes of parameters for synaptic efficacy and neural excitability that could improve action selection ability and at the same time reduce oscillations. Identification of such targets could potentially generate ideas for treatments of PD and increase our understanding of the relation between network dynamics and network function.
This is the published version in [doi: 10.1523/ENEURO.0156-16.2016](https://doi.org/10.1523/ENEURO.0156-16.2016)

35882a62-2a4f-4410-a30e-c13ac797f3f7.name: Object Recognition for Scene Understanding
35882a62-2a4f-4410-a30e-c13ac797f3f7.description: A convolutional neural network model which recognizes objects based on snapshots obtained from Neurorobotic Platform (NRP). A simulated icub robot was used to capture the images. The images were captured using icub left (eye) camera. The icub gazes upon objects belonging to 10 object categories. The resulting images were then resampled (distorted) using ganglion cell distributions in the retina.

36090403-02a2-4934-8f99-4ed0d11440cc.name: Rat Hippocampus CA1
36090403-02a2-4934-8f99-4ed0d11440cc.description:

Authors only include first author and PIs in alphabetic order. The list of authors will be finalized at the time of publication.

Usage. To use the model, you have to:
1. copy the model to your cluster
2. go to circuit/connectome/functional and follow instructions in README file
3. update the paths in in circuit/CircuitConfig
4. steps 1-3 are sufficient to enable you to analyze the circuit
5. for simulation, you can use either the BSP SimUI or the BBP Neurodamus

3614b4ce-9131-4b33-b92c-e0e59157c858.name: Anthropomorphic Reach RNN
3614b4ce-9131-4b33-b92c-e0e59157c858.description:
![Animation of robot hand touching thumb to fingers](https://camo.githubusercontent.com/27bfd7d77ae770566e9d485fa7cebc8f96e6f26c929ab08f31a9621ad5229029/68747470733a2f2f692e706f7374696d672e63632f5a5967575271464d2f68616e6472656163682e676966)

We have developed an artificial agent controling the joints of a simulated anthropomorphic robotic hand with an artificial neural network model as a policy. Training is conducted in a deep reinforcement learning setting, that is, the agent learns by exploring its environment through initially random actions and gradually adjusting its policy network to maximize a task-specific reward. As a precursor to the in-hand object manipulation task this system is eventually applied to, we have trained the agent on the archetypal task of reaching. Here, the agent must steer the joints of the hand to join random fingers with the thumb above the palm. To that end, our model is a recurrent neural network. The input to this network are the current angles and velocities of the hand's joints, as well as the target positions of the fingertips. This information is abstracted in 4 fully connected layers followed by one gated recurrent unit, which the agent can utilize to represent memory in the policy. The network's output are the parameters of a Beta distributed joint probability density function. Each marginal distribution corresponds to one joint and represents the absolute angle into which the agent wants to move this joint at the current timestep. The actual target angle communicated to the simulation is sampled from this distribution randomly.
An artificial neural network modeling the frontoparietal network of the primate brain with macro-level plausibility has been trained from scratch to manipulate a cube by controlling an anthropomorphic robotic hand (in simulation). The provided files comprise network weight and preprocessing parameters. Model definitions and task simulations can be found in the repository. The pretrained model can be used for further training or analysis.

36b2d233-2ac0-48fa-986f-c9f25b5fc631.name: Probabilistic localization by rodent grid cells
36b2d233-2ac0-48fa-986f-c9f25b5fc631.description:
A model of grid cell activity in the mEC. Grid cells recursively combine environmental sensory inputs, mediated via place cells, with path integration mediated by animal self-motion, to compute an optimal estimate of location at each time step.

For more implementation details, see Evans and Burgess (2019), NeurIPS.

3772094a-8e2d-4075-8f05-9be62c8d8a5d.name: Dichotomy of action-potential backpropagation in CA1 pyramidal neuron dendrites (Golding et al 2001)
3772094a-8e2d-4075-8f05-9be62c8d8a5d.description:
A model of CA1 pyramidal neurons (ModelDB accession number: 64167), as described in:

Golding NL, Kath WL, Spruston N (2001) Dichotomy of action-potential backpropagation in CA1 pyramidal neuron dendrites. *J. Neurophysiol.* **86**:2998-3010 [doi:10.1152/jn.2001.86.6.2998](http://doi.org/10.1152/jn.2001.86.6.2998)

The model was developed to show the dichotomy of the back-propagation efficacy and the amplitudes of the back-propagating action potentials at distal trunk regions in CA1 pyramidal cells and to make predictions on the possible causes of this behaviour. It contains only the most important ion channels (Na, KDR,KA) needed to reproduce the generation and propagation of action potentials. Here we tested three different versions of the model: the ones belonging to the Figure 8 A, Figure 8 B and Figure 9 B of the corresponding paper.
Original code via ModelDB

3ca9ae35-c9df-451f-ac76-4925bd2c7dc6.name: AdEx Neuron Models with PyNN
3ca9ae35-c9df-451f-ac76-4925bd2c7dc6.description:
Adaptive exponential integrate-and-fire (aeIF) neuron models for different cell types:

     - RS (Regular Spiking) pyramidal cells (excitatory)
     - RSw (weakly adapting Regular Spiking) pyramidal cell (excitatory)
     - FS (Fast Spiking) interneuron cells (inhibitory) with negligible adaptation.
     - LTS (Low Threshold Spiking) cortical cell (excitatory)
     - TC (ThalamoCortical) thalamic cell (excitatory)
     - RE (Reticular thalamic nucleus) thalamic cells (inhibitory)

This script reproduces Figure 1 of the following article:

Destexhe A (2009) Self-sustained asynchronous irregular states and Up-Down states inthalamic, cortical and thalamocortial networks of nonlinear integrate-and-fire neurons. J Computat Neurosci 27:493-506
DOI 10.1007/s10827-009-0164-4

In the figure we see the response of each cell type to a depolarizing current pulse of 0.25nA or a hyperpolarizing current pulse -0.25nA.

3d8393a1-498c-4e6d-b31d-f578b285bceb.name: Biophysical and phenomenological models of multiple spike interactions in spike-timing dependent plasticity
3d8393a1-498c-4e6d-b31d-f578b285bceb.description: Spike-timing dependent plasticity (STDP) is a form of associative synaptic modification which depends on the respective timing of pre- and post-synaptic spikes. The biophysical mechanisms underlying this form of plasticity are currently not known. We present here a biophysical model which captures the characteristics of STDP, such as its frequency dependency, and the effects of spike pair or spike triplet interactions. We also make links with other well-known plasticity rules. A simplified phenomenological model is also derived, which should be useful for fast numerical simulation and analytical investigation of the impact of STDP at the network level.

3ff4367a-ea8f-402c-b75f-5bdeed876940.description:
A model of CA1 pyramidal neurons, as described in:

M. Migliore, I. De Blasi, D. Tegolo, R. Migliore (2011) A modeling study suggesting how a reduction in the context-dependent input on CA1 pyramidal neurons could generate schizophrenic behavior. *Neural Networks* **24**:552-559 [doi:10.1016/j.neunet.2011.01.001](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neunet.2011.01.001)

The model (ModelDB accession number: 138205) was used to study schizophrenic behaviour, and is based on models from the same modeling group, which were used to investigate the initiation and propagation of action potentials in oblique dendrites, and have been validated against a number of different electrophysiological data.
This version is the original code from ModelDB.

422f2b8e-3b7d-4a01-aa2f-2dcb2270e1cd.name: The Virtual Epileptic Patient
422f2b8e-3b7d-4a01-aa2f-2dcb2270e1cd.description:
The virtual patient brain network model allows a novel approach to brain interventions based on large-scale brain network based models that are derived from non- invasive structural data of individual patients. The Virtual Epileptic Patient (VEP) model provides the perfect test bed for clinical hypothesis testing of questions linked to network-based mechanisms. 
Large-scale brain network models in general, and the VEP brain model in particular, have three critical components, network connectivity, neural mass model and MRI lesions. First, procedures to reconstruct connectivity from dMRI data nowadays reliably extract structural network connectivity with high anatomical precision (Johansen-Berg and Berhens, 2009) and efforts are on the way to develop more advanced methods proving robust and reproducible on subject and group levels (Besson et al., 2014). Thus there is hope that patient specific connectomes may soon enter in clinical routine use. Second, neural mass models are placed at the network nodes and determine the dynamic nature of the interactions. Neural mass models need not necessarily to be derived from biophysical mechanisms, but rather need to capture the dynamic repertoire of the neural population. It is in this dynamical sense that they have to be biophysically realistic, not in the traditional bottom-up causal sense. In epilepsy, the Epileptor is a neural mass model that has been derived purely based on mathematical reasoning. It provides a complete taxonomy of epileptic seizures including onset, offset and seizure evolution characteristics. Once a seizure type has been determined for a particular patient, then the taxonomy by (Jirsa et al., 2014) offers a mathematical formulation of a generative model that can be used as a network node in the VEP model. Third, integration of MRI lesions into the VEP model is possible, but not evident due to the challenge in translating the lesion into model parameters. Reasonable candidates are excitability and local connectivity, because localized tis- sue abnormalities are likely to alter these two parameters in the context of our network perspective. MRI lesions provide a spatial map of altered parameters that thus enter into the VEP model and affect the network dynamics. The emergent dynamic effects, that are the seizures in the current context, will crucially depend on the interplay between net- work node model (Epileptor), patient specific structural connectivity (from dMRI), and spatial maps of excitability (EZ, PZ) and MRI lesions.

The model allows reconstructing epileptic patients’ brain networks, using their specific anatomical properties and the Epileptor, a neural mass model that captures the temporal evolution of a seizure including on- and offset. Based on clinical hypothesis of the epileptogenic zone (EZ), the model can reproduce seizure propagation in silico as observed empirically with SEEG electrodes implanted in the patient. These propagation patterns cannot be captured by functional connectivity due to their inherent non-stationarity. 
The model allows modeling that includes the following steps: 
1) Proix et al (2016) built the processing chain of all structural images (dMRI, MRI) required to build a virtual brain. 
2) Jirsa et al (2017) demonstrated the methodology and proof of concept of how to create personalized models and fit them against empirical neuroimaging data. 3) Proix et al (2017) performed a pilot study (N=15), where we computed a score estimating the difference between the EZ identified by the brain model, and that identified by the clinicians during pre-surgical evaluation. This study demonstrated the favourable correlation between model prediction and surgery outcome. In other words: negative surgery outcome correlates with surgery not performed in line with model predictions.

### References: 
Jirsa, V. K. et al. The Virtual Epileptic Patient: Individualized whole-brain models of epilepsy spread. Neuroimage (2016). [doi:10.1016/j.neuroimage.2016.04.049](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2016.04.049)
Proix, T. et al. How do parcellation size and short-range connectivity affect dynamics in large-scale brain network models? Neuroimage (2016). [doi:10.1016/j.neuroimage.2016.06.016](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2016.06.016)
Proix T, Bartolomei F, Guye M, Jirsa V. Individual brain structure and modelling predict seizure propagation. Brain 140, 641–654 (2017).
Jirsa, VK, Stacey WC, Quilichini PP, Ivanov A, Bernard C, 2014. On the nature of seizure dynamics. Brain 137, 2210–2230. [doi:10.1093/brain/awu133.](https://doi.org/10.1093/brain/awu133).

44ce578d-0974-423e-a414-840ce182e82f.name: Network model of spontaneous activity in cortex
44ce578d-0974-423e-a414-840ce182e82f.description:
The UNIC partner has studied the activity and responsiveness of cortical networks of Adaptive Exponential (AdEx) integrate and fire neurons, using a similar model as described previously (Destexhe, JCNS, 2009; see this paper for all details about the methods).  Such networks can be used to simulate the different firing patterns of excitatory (“regular spiking” or RS) and inhibitory (“fast spiking” or FS) neurons (Fig. 1A).  RS-FS networks display different states ranging from synchronous-regular (SR) to asynchronous-irregular (AI) states (Fig. 1B).  Interestingly, the response of the network was higher in the AI state, compared to any other state of the network (Fig. 1C-D).  The responsiveness of the network can be understood from reconstructing the transfer function of its neurons (Fig. 1E-F).

Remarkably, one can see that the AI state is highly responsive (Fig. 1D), but not all AI states produce the same response.  This was due to the fact that one of the network (VA-2005) had a too strong conductance, while the RS-FS network was tuned to the conductances measured experimentally in vivo (Fig. 1E).  Reconstructing the theoretical transfer function from these two networks shows that the strong conductance shifted the response of the neurons to high input weights, which explains the lack of responsiveness (Fig. 1F, green).  On the other hand, the RS-FS network displayed a response curve which was overlapping with the stimulus (Fig. 1F, blue) and thus the network was responsive to this input.

To investigate larger-scale consequences of this responsiveness, we simulated a paradigm consisting of successive layers of RS-FS networks (Fig. 2).  A pulse packet given as input in the first layer could reliably propagate across layers, but only in the AI state (Fig. 2B).  Such a propagation was not possible in AI states that had implausible conductance levels (not shown). 

We conclude that AI state provide very interesting responsiveness properties, but only if they have a physiologically realistic conductance level.  This was confirmed by analyzing a very wide range of AI states (Girones and Destexhe, 2017).  This property makes them able to detect inputs and propagate them across layers.  This may explain why the awake brain is always associated to “desynchronized” activity, and why the brain switches to this type of activity when performing a task, or attending to stimuli.  We thus propose that AI states can implement a low-level form of sensory awareness (Zerlaut and Destexhe, 2017).

**[Program code of the model is available in ModelDB](https://senselab.med.yale.edu/modeldb/ShowModel?model=234992#tabs-1)**

**[PyNN program code of the model in ZIP](https://mycore.core-cloud.net/index.php/s/8N0DCUjHgrTbtPr)**



Publications

Zerlaut Y. and Destexhe A. Enhanced responsiveness and low-level awareness in stochastic network states.  Neuron 92: 1002-1009, 2017.

Girones Z. and Destexhe A. Enhanced responsiveness in asynchronous irregular neuronal networks.   [arXiv preprint](https://arxiv.org/abs/1611.09089)

456c1fac-39dd-4451-a768-9a4637d59b86.name: Active Model of Human Cortical Pyramidal Neurons in Layer 2/3 - Cell 3/0603
456c1fac-39dd-4451-a768-9a4637d59b86.description:
A morphological and electrophysiological model of human pyramidal cells in layer 2/3.

This model is one of the six human layer 2 and layer 3 pyramidal cells that were modeled, integrating detailed anatomical and physiological data from both fresh and postmortem tissues from human temporal cortex.

A Live Paper introduces interactively this modeled human L2/3 neurons, including their morphology, experimental measurements and modelling response to current and synaptic input, see  [Eyal et al., 2018](https://doi.org/10.25493/XFX6-3QD).

More details can be found in the following paper:
"Human Cortical Pyramidal Neurons: From Spines to Spikes via Models" Eyal Guy, Verhoog Matthijs B., Testa-Silva Guilherme, Deitcher Yair, Benavides-Piccione Ruth, DeFelipe Javier, de Kock Christiaan P. J., Mansvelder Huibert D., Segev Idan. [https://doi.org/10.3389/fncel.2018.00181](https://doi.org/10.3389/fncel.2018.00181)

45814458-9551-46f8-9559-b30ffe670413.name: Mean field model for Hodgkin Huxley networks of neurons
45814458-9551-46f8-9559-b30ffe670413.description:
In SGA2, we have developed a semi-analytic approach to mean-field models [1].  This approach is very powerful because one can use it to design mean-field models from complex neural models.  It was applied first to networks of AdEx neurons with conductance-based synaptic interactions [1].  The formalism was later extended to include spike-frequency adaptation [2], which enabled us to obtain mean-field models that very finely capture the time course and amplitude of response to external stimulation.  At the end of SGA2, we took it one step further by designing mean-field models of even more complex models, the Morris-Lecar model and the well-known Hodgkin-Huxley (HH) model [3].  The mean-field model captures the level of spontaneous activity and the dynamics of response of networks of HH neurons.  In SGA3, we plan to apply this formalism to detailed models based on morphological reconstructions.

It is important to note that part of this work was obtained during the EITN Spring School of Computational Neuroscience, and we decided to put the students as co-first authors of the resulting article [3].

A copy of the code of this model was put in open-access on [ModelDB]( https://senselab.med.yale.edu/modeldb/ShowModel?model=263259)


References

[1] Zerlaut, Y., Chemla, S., Chavane, F. and Destexhe, A.  Modeling mesoscopic cortical dynamics using a mean-field model of conductance-based networks of adaptive exponential integrate-and-fire neurons. J. Computational Neurosci. 44: 45-61, 2018.

[2] di Volo, M., Romagnoni, A., Capone, C. and Destexhe, A. Biologically realistic mean-field models of conductance-based networks of spiking neurons with adaptation. Neural Computation 31: 653-680, 2019. 

[3] Carlu, M., Chehab, O., Dalla Porta, L., Depannemaecker, D., Herice, C., Jedynak, M., Koksal, Ersoz, E., Muratore, P., Souihel, S., Capone, C., Zerlaut, Y., Destexhe, A. and di Volo, M.  A mean-field approach to the dynamics of networks of complex neurons, from nonlinear Integrate-and-Fire to Hodgkin-Huxley models. J. Neurophysiol., in press, 2020.
https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/870345v1

459a2b17-bcb7-4835-822d-9fa7e3395a8f.name: Mean-field Model of AdEx networks
459a2b17-bcb7-4835-822d-9fa7e3395a8f.description:
The UNIC partner has designed a mean-field model of neuronal population activity, for networks of Adaptive Exponential (AdEx) integrate and fire neurons.  The model of spiking neurons (used as a reference) was a similar model as described previously (Destexhe, JCNS, 2009; see this paper for all details about the methods).  The network was based on two different cell types, excitatory (“regular spiking” or RS) and inhibitory (“fast spiking” or FS) neurons.  The mean-field model of RS-FS networks was based on a Master Equation Formalism proposed previously (El Boustani and Destexhe, 2009).  

We report here the first results of a mean-field model of RS-FS networks.  Such a model requires to compute the transfer functions of the different cell types, which we have done for RS and FS cells, numerically.  The mean-field model obtained was then tested against numerical simulations of the network.  The mean-field model was able to capture the distribution of firing rates during spontaneous activity (Fig. 1), as well as the response of the network to external excitatory inputs (Fig. 2).   One can see that the mean-field predicts well the activity of these networks, as well as the temporal dynamics of their responses to simple stimuli.  However, the peak and the tail of the responses were not perfectly fit, mostly because of the presence of adaptation in RS cells.  The inclusion of an adaptation term is currently being investigated.

An extension of the model is towards including measurements of transfer functions from real cortical neurons.  The transfer function is a central piece of the mean-field formalism, it maps the output of the neuron (expressed as a rate) as a function of its excitatory and inhibitory inputs.  One great advantage of the Master Equation formalism (El Boustani and Destexhe, 2009) is that it can be applied to any network of neurons, provided their transfer functions are known.  It was initially applied networks of integrate-and-fire neurons, connected with conductance-based synapses, and the formalism successfully predicted the state space of such networks (El Boustani and Destexhe, 2009).  It was more recently applied to more complex neuron types, such as the AdEx model (Zerlaut and Destexhe, 2017).  Here, the transfer function was obtained using a semi-analytical procedure, where a mathematical template was fit to numerical simulations (Zerlaut and Destexhe, 2017).   The resulting mean-field model could predict not only the level of spontaneous activity, but also the response of the network to external stimuli, as shown above.

The same approach could be followed for more complex neurons, and it was applied to real neurons from mouse V1 (Zerlaut et al., 2016).  In this approach, the same mathematical template was used and was constrained to recordings of neurons using conductance-based inputs injected using the dynamic-clamp technique.  This technique allowed us to measure the transfer function from 30 neurons, electrophysiologically identified as RS neurons.  However, the experiments revealed a very strong cell-to-cell diversity of transfer functions, which could only be accounted by diversity in the level of excitability of the neurons.  Mean-field models based on real neurons are potentially powerful because they can be used to match population recordings from real data - this new type of mean-field model will be investigated in SGA2.

Publications

Zerlaut Y. and Destexhe A. (2017) A mean-field model for conductance-based networks of adaptive exponential integrate-and-fire models.  
ArXiv preprint: https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.00698 

Zerlaut Y., Chemla, S., Chavane F. and Destexhe A. (2018) Modeling mesoscopic cortical dynamics using a mean-field model of conductance-based networks of adaptive exponential integrate-and-fire models.  Journal of Computational Neuroscience (in press).
bioRxiv preprint: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/11/12/abs/168385

Zerlaut Y., Telenczuk, B., Deleuze, C., Bal, T., Ouanounou, G. and Destexhe, A. (2016)  Heterogeneous firing rate response of mice layer V pyramidal neurons in the fluctuation-driven regime. Journal of Physiology 594: 3791-3808.

References

El Boustani, S. and Destexhe, A.  A master equation formalism for macroscopic modeling of asynchronous irregular activity states.  Neural Computation 21: 46-100, 2009.

Code: https://senselab.med.yale.edu/modeldb/ShowModel.cshtml?model=234992#tabs-1

46770371-345e-445f-b474-641db1eef3f2.name: Striatum microcircuit
46770371-345e-445f-b474-641db1eef3f2.description:
Simulation of the striatal microcircuit. The network model reproduces electrical activity within a given volume of striatal tissue, populated with striatal projection neurons of the direct and indirect pathways (dSPN and iSPN), fast-spiking interneurons (FS), low-threshold spiking interneurons (LTS) and cholinergic interneurons (ChIN).

Related publication: Hjorth et al. (2020) The microcircuits of striatum in silico. PNAS 117 (17) 9554-9565; [doi:10.1073/pnas.2000671117](https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2000671117)

![fig 1](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_c0a333ecf7c045809321ce9d9ecdfdea/Grillner_SGA2_T6.2.4/striatum/network/2020Q1/F1C.small.png)

Schematic connectivity within dSTR involving dSPN, iSPN, FS, LTS, and ChIN. Connection probabilities within and between neuronal subtypes are shown by respective arrows; numbers in red correspond to connection probabilities for a somatic pair at a distance of 50 μm, while numbers in blue correspond to 100 μm.

![fig2](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_c0a333ecf7c045809321ce9d9ecdfdea/Grillner_SGA2_T6.2.4/striatum/network/2020Q1/F10.small.jpeg)

Network simulation of 10,000 neurons. (A) The activity of the network is shown in the form of a raster plot (Bottom) and spike histogram (Top). (B) Example traces of each cell type in the network are shown. The network is driven with cortical and thalamic input and modulated by dopamine, as indicated at the Top of the figure and the shaded areas (in A and B, respectively). The three inputs represent 1) baseline activation of cortical and thalamic input (thal+crtx baseline), 2) a cortical command signal (crtx cmd), during which the cortical activation is increased (given to all cells except the ChINs), and 3) a dopaminergic modulation signal that acts on conductances of the ion channels.
Network model setup for simulation of 10,000 neurons from the mouse striatum tissue. Reproduces Figure 10 by Hjorth et al. (2020).

49b21755-313b-432c-93ba-e6812b006077.name: Simulation of a Free Energy Landscape of Neuroreceptor/Ligand Unbinding using Metadynamics
49b21755-313b-432c-93ba-e6812b006077.description:
This model is designed to explore  unbinding of the iperoxo agonist from its target human neuroreceptor M2, embedded in a neuronal membrane. The protocol includes two steps: (i)  identifying a few essential reaction coordinates from non-equilibrium molecular simulations, and (ii)  reconstruction a full free energy unbinding landscape using an  enhanced sampling method (well-tempered metadynamics in its funnel variant) based on reaction coordinates.
The data and scripts include: (I)  the structure and input files for the M2 muscarinic receptor with iperoxo, (II) the plumed file for Ratcheted MD, (III) the plumed file for funnel metadynamics, and (IV) the input file for the reweighting procedure.

Model was published in J. Chem. Theory Comput. 2019, 15, 5, 3354-3361
Riccardo Capelli, Anna Bochicchio,GiovanniMaria Piccini, Rodrigo Casasnovas, Paolo Carloni, Michele Parrinello "Chasing the Full Free Energy Landscape of Neuroreceptor/Ligand Unbinding by Metadynamics Simulations",
[doi:10.1021/acs.jctc.9b00118](https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.jctc.9b00118)

4c5d8992-f2d4-43ad-bb27-23b98836e59b.name: CA1 pyramidal neuron: as a 2-layer neural network and subthreshold synaptic summation
4c5d8992-f2d4-43ad-bb27-23b98836e59b.description:
The Poirazi et al. (2003) model ([ModelDB accession number: 20212](http://modeldb.yale.edu/20212)) was designed to clarify issues about the integrative properties of thin apical dendrites, which may arise from the different and sometimes conflicting interpretation of available experimental data. This is a quite complex model in the sense that it contains a larger number of different types of ion channels, whose properties were adjusted to fit *in vitro* experimental data, and it also contains four types of synaptic receptors.

"euler" methods in cad.mod and gabab.mod were updated to "derivimplicit"  and "cnexp" respectively as per http://www.neuron.yale.edu/phpbb/viewtopic.php?f=28&t=592
