a904e43c-84c1-46d0-85b1-21377787214f.name: Active Inference computational model of active whisking
a904e43c-84c1-46d0-85b1-21377787214f.description: This is a computational model of active whisking based on the framework of active inference, which describes action and perception as guided by an overall process of minimisation of prediction errors (Friston, 2005; Rao & Ballard, 1999); or more formally, a minimisation of variational free energy (Friston, 2010; Parr et al., 2022). The computational model is inspired by previous findings about how rats and mice adapt their whisking kinematics to optimise their whisker placement during tactile sensing. Across several studies, it emerged that rats and mice use an anticipatory strategy to adapt their whisker amplitude to the distance (and location) in which they expect to encounter objects (Voigts et al., 2015). In other words, they might form an internal prediction based on a (memorised) expectation of the location of an object and adapt their whisking behaviour accordingly. To explain these findings, we adopt an active inference perspective and hypothesize that the brain generates object-specific predictions about whisker protractions and touches and treats unexpected whisker contacts as prediction error signals (discrepancies between the expectation and reality), to be minimised by adjusting whisker behaviour.

b00e6ebe-a633-4266-a221-0414d22efd4d.name: Mouse CA1 pyramidal neuron model, morphology mpg150218_A1_idA
b00e6ebe-a633-4266-a221-0414d22efd4d.description:
This model is part of a collection of ten distinct single-cell computational models of mouse CA1 pyramidal neurons, created using a well-established computational workflow, and ready to be used in a full-scale hippocampal circuit. This data-driven model is based on a 3D reconstruction of a biocytin-stained cell morphology using Neurolucida and on electrophysiological features extracted from data collected from mice by patch-clamp, and implemented using the BluePyOpt algorithm.
This version of the model is the one used in Vitale et al. (2023) [doi:10.3389/fncel.2023.1281932](https://doi.org/10.3389/fncel.2023.1281932)

b0c72944-6dd1-4076-912b-ba825f1ab8aa.name: Network model of Up-Down slow oscillations in L5 cortex of sleeping and anesthetized mammals
b0c72944-6dd1-4076-912b-ba825f1ab8aa.description:
Here, we provide a simulation of a cortical-like module endowed with activity-dependent adaptation. Fundamental aspects of the local responses elicited in mammals by direct cortical stimulation can be replicated by systematically varying the relationships between adaptation strength and excitation level in the network.

The spiking neuron network presented here has been adapted from [Torao-Angosto et al. (2021)](https://doi.org/10.3389/fnsys.2021.609645). The network was built using anatomical data collected in the literature on L5 of the visual cortex of sleeping and anesthetized rats (v1).

More specifically the network parameters were chosen to model a self-consistent network of Layer 5 neurons each having an average number of pre-synaptic connections computed considering the connection probabilities described in [Markram et al. (2015)](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnsys.2021.609645/full#B17), the cellular densities reported in [Beaulieu (1993)](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnsys.2021.609645/full#B2) and the exponential decay of the cortico-cortical connectivity across layers reported in [Schnepel et al. (2015)](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnsys.2021.609645/full#B34) and in [Kätzel et al. (2011)](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnsys.2021.609645/full#B14) for excitatory and inhibitory pre-synaptic sources, respectively. As result, excitatory neurons received on average 2,910 (129) synaptic contacts from E (I) neurons, while the inhibitory ones received 746 (45) connections from E (I) pre-synaptic cells. To model a 1 mm<sup>2</sup>-patch of the cortex only 2% of excitatory connections were considered to be recurrent. Synaptic efficacies were set to have—under mean-field approximation—a fixed point with a firing rate of 0.75 Hz and 4.375 Hz for excitatory and inhibitory neurons ([Watson et al., 2016](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnsys.2021.609645/full#B37)), respectively.

Then the network is made of interconnected leaky integrate-and-fire excitatory and inhibitory neurons. Excitatory neurons incorporate the activity-dependent fatigue mechanism modeling spike-frequency adaptation (SFA), which is a key ingredient to generate Up-Down slow oscillations typical of deep sleep and anesthesia. We provide the Python code, and associated explanations, to generate dynamics for several adaptation and excitation levels.

The instructions for running the simulations are inserted into the Jupyter notebook (`Simulations_spiking
 neuron network.ipynb`) as comments.

b115de80-9524-4e84-a3f9-b40816ab3753.name: Benchmark model 2 from Brette et al. (2007)
b115de80-9524-4e84-a3f9-b40816ab3753.description:
The review article Brette et al. (2007) (see related publications) defined a number of benchmark models that were implemented with different simulation tools and/or programming languages.

Benchmark 2 was a network of IF neurons connected with current-based (CUBA) synapses, based on Vogels & Abbott (2005).
This is the implementation for PyNN v0.10.1.

b2616cba-d4cb-47c9-8caf-f601f76e7250.name: Scaffold Model of Cerebellum microcircuit
b2616cba-d4cb-47c9-8caf-f601f76e7250.description:
Microcircuit model of Cerebellum from [https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fninf.2019.00037/full](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fninf.2019.00037/full)

A scaffold model of the cerebellum has been developed in order to flexibly place neurons in space, connect them synaptically, and endow neurons and synapses with biologically-grounded mechanisms. The scaffold is designed to integrate the cerebellar cortex with deep cerebellar nuclei (DCN), including different neuronal types: Golgi cells, granule cells, Purkinje cells, stellate cells, basket cells, and DCN principal cells. Mossy fiber inputs were conveyed through the glomeruli. Reconstruction follows sequential steps: cells placement in 3D space and connectome according to geometric rules. Simulations run within the PyNEST environment. 

Reference

Casali S, Marenzi E, Medini C, Casellato C, D'Angelo E (2019) Reconstruction and Simulation of a Scaffold Model of the Cerebellar Network. Frontiers in Neuroinformatics 13:37, [doi:10.3389/fninf.2019.00037](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fninf.2019.00037/full)

b2d853aa-ebef-40a5-8af9-aefe0b566c45.name: A two-stage model of dendritic integration in CA1 pyramidal neurons (Katz et al., 2009)
b2d853aa-ebef-40a5-8af9-aefe0b566c45.description:
A model of hippocampus CA1 pyramidal neurons (ModelDB accession number: 127351), described in:

Katz Y, Menon V, Nicholson DA, Geinisman Y, Kath WL, Spruston N (2009) Synapse distribution suggests a two-stage model of dendritic integration in CA1 pyramidal neurons. *Neuron* **63**:171-7 [doi:10.1016/j.neuron.2009.06.023](http://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuron.2009.06.023)

and based on the Golding et al. (2001) model. It was built to investigate the functional consequences of the distribution of strength and density of synapses on the apical dendrites, as observed experimentally, on the mode of dendritic integration.

We provide here both the original code (via ModelDB) and a version with a Python wrapper for the SciUnit model validation framework.
This is the original version, via ModelDB.

b4e5e4f9-0280-47ec-ad1e-bd81f632ceea.name: Visual target selection
b4e5e4f9-0280-47ec-ad1e-bd81f632ceea.description: Our model is based on a winner-takes-all (WTA) decision making model. In a free-viewing paradigm, several salient objects cause competition in the frontal eye fields (FEF) neurons so as to ensure fixation on one of the objects for a few (milli)seconds until another salient object causes the corresponding FEF neurons to ‘win’. Hence, we extend the WTA model to include switching behaviour. Switching implies that the two populations compete and alternate between high and low firing activity. Without such a mechanism, a simple WTA model would stay forever in one attractor state. A probable underlying mechanism for switching behaviour is the existence of a negative feedback loop between motor and visual neurons.

b7ed7c3b-02c5-4d11-8793-3fabaf8c6dc5.name: Sparsely connected networks of excitatory and inhibitory neurons - Brunel, 2000
b7ed7c3b-02c5-4d11-8793-3fabaf8c6dc5.description: The dynamics of networks of sparsely connected excitatory and inhibitory integrate-and-fire neurons are studied analytically (and with simulations). The analysis reveals a rich repertoire of states, including synchronous states in which neurons fire regularly; asynchronous states with stationary global activity and very irregular individual cell activity; and states in which the global activity oscillates but individual cells fire irregularly, typically at rates lower than the global oscillation frequency. See paper for more and details. Brunel N (2000) Dynamics of sparsely connected networks of excitatory and inhibitory spiking neurons. J Comput Neurosci 8:183-208.

b9416d3f-d7d6-480e-bc8a-9f2390d38246.name: Model of neurovascular coupling via astrocytic calcium dynamics
b9416d3f-d7d6-480e-bc8a-9f2390d38246.description:
Model of neurovascular coupling introduced in the article:

"Modeling the relationship between neuronal activity and the BOLD signal: Contributions from astrocyte calcium dynamics", Tesler et al., Scientific Reports, 2023. 

The code to run the demo is in the file `Integration_rk_1stO_BOLD_Astro.py`, which includes the simulations of the mean-field model of neuronal activity, the astrocytic calcium dynamics, the vascular response and the BOLD signal.
This is version 2 in Zenodo

b9a984c8-cc75-4491-92ab-61482e8d12e0.name: Passive Model of Human Cortical Pyramidal Neurons in Layer 2/3 - Cell 3/0603
b9a984c8-cc75-4491-92ab-61482e8d12e0.description:
A morphological and passive electrophysiological model of human pyramidal cells in layer 2/3.

This model is one of the six human layer 2 and layer 3 pyramidal cells that were modeled, integrating detailed anatomical and physiological data from both fresh and postmortem tissues from human temporal cortex. This model focuses on the passive electrophysiological properties of the neuron,

More details can be found in the following paper:
"[Unique membrane properties and enhanced signal processing in human neocortical neurons](https://elifesciences.org/articles/16553 )" Guy Eyal, Matthijs B Verhoog, Guilherme Testa-Silva, Yair Deitcher, Johannes C Lodder, Ruth Benavides-Piccione, Juan Morales, Javier DeFelipe, Christiaan PJ de Kock, Huibert D Mansvelder, Idan Segev

ba7a45c5-3f9f-4d25-a63b-f15b48cdf548.name: INST/FILT Learning Rule
ba7a45c5-3f9f-4d25-a63b-f15b48cdf548.description:
Precise spike timing as a means to encode information in neural
                  networks is biologically supported, and is
                  advantageous over frequency-based codes by
                  processing input features on a much shorter
                  time-scale. For these reasons, much recent attention
                  has been focused on the development of supervised
                  learning rules for spiking neural networks that
                  utilise a temporal coding scheme. However, despite
                  significant progress in this area, there still lack
                  rules that have a theoretical basis, and yet can be
                  considered biologically relevant. Here we examine
                  the general conditions under which synaptic
                  plasticity most effectively takes place to support
                  the supervised learning of a precise temporal
                  code. As part of our analysis we examine two
                  spike-based learning methods: one of which relies on
                  an instantaneous error signal to modify synaptic
                  weights in a network (INST rule), and the other one
                  relying on a filtered error signal for smoother
                  synaptic weight modifications (FILT rule). We test
                  the accuracy of the solutions provided by each rule
                  with respect to their temporal encoding precision,
                  and then measure the maximum number of input
                  patterns they can learn to memorise using the
                  precise timings of individual spikes as an
                  indication of their storage capacity. Our results
                  demonstrate the high performance of the FILT rule in
                  most cases, underpinned by the rule’s
                  error-filtering mechanism, which is predicted to
                  provide smooth convergence towards a desired
                  solution during learning. We also find the FILT rule
                  to be most efficient at performing input pattern
                  memorisations, and most noticeably when patterns are
                  identified using spikes with sub-millisecond
                  temporal precision. In comparison with existing
                  work, we determine the performance of the FILT rule
                  to be consistent with that of the highly efficient
                  E-learning Chronotron rule, but with the distinct
                  advantage that our FILT rule is also implementable
                  as an online method for increased biological
                  realism.
version as published at http://dx.doi.org/10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0161335

bad659c6-f585-4bb4-bb4c-11a2822dc94b.name: Topological Similarity
bad659c6-f585-4bb4-bb4c-11a2822dc94b.description:
The quest to understand how the structural network of interconnections shapes brain function lies at the heart of the field of brain connectivity. So far, we still lack a unitary model of the relationship between the shape of the brain’s connectome and the emergent activity patterns. One of the main reasons is that interactions between different brain areas do not only depend on the structure of the connectome but also on the local and global dynamics characterizing a given brain state, such as rest, sleep, and anesthesia. The existence of different state dependent activity patterns sustained by the same underlying anatomy exposes how elusive is the relationship between the network structure and function.

This model, named as *topological similarity*, is an analytical estimate of the contribution of the structural brain connectivity alone on the cross-correlations between brain areas, discarding the influence of higher order dynamical influences. The model is based on three axiomatic assumptions on the diffusion of influence or information over the network:

1. In a network, information travels along all possible paths (with equal probability). Very often, network approaches of information transmission consider only the shortest paths.
2. Information content (or signal power) decays with path distance. This assumption implies that despite information travels along all possible paths, shorter paths are still more influencial than longer paths.
3. Two brain regions are correlated if they receive inputs from the same sources.

The first two assumptions define how information travels along a network and determine how much the dynamics of one brain region affected the dynamics of any other brain region. Given that the structural connectivity is encoded by the weighted adjacency matrix **A**, where A(i,j) > 0 if there is a link pointing from region *i* to region *j* and A(i,j) = 0 if no such link exist, then the influence between any pair of nodes can be quantified by the communicability measure *C*. By definition, communicability is the matrix exponential of the adjacency matrix, *C* = exp(g**A**), which is a weighted sum of the powers of the adjacency matrix, and *g* is a parameter for global coupling strength.

$$\mathcal{C} = e^{gA} = \mathbf{1} + gA + \frac{(gA)^2}{2!}  + \frac{(gA)^3}{3!} + \ldots$$

$$\mathcal{T} = \frac{\left< \mathbf{c}\_i, \mathbf{c}\_j \right>}{|\mathbf{c}\_i| \, |\mathbf{c}\_j|}$$

Applying this model to structural human brain connectivity we were able to estimate the cross-correlations between brain regions which are expected in resting-state only due to the connectivity alone, Fig. 1(M) for one hemisphere and Fig. 1(N) for the whole brain. Comparing to empirically observed functional connectivities via fMRI during resting-state, Fig. 1(E) and (F), we could quantify that the shape of the brain's connectome only accounts for up to 45% of the empirical functional connectivity.


#### Publications

R.G. Bettinardi, **G. Deco**, V.M. Karlaftis, T.J. Van Hartevelt, H. M. Fernandes, Z. Kourtzi, M.L. Kringelbach, and **G. Zamora-López** "*[How structure sculpts function: Unveiling the contribution of anatomical connectivity to the brain’s spontaneous correlation structure](http://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.4980099)*" CHAOS **27**, 047409 (2017).

#### Code Availability
Source code to calculate the Topological Similarity from a given network is found as a function in [pyGAlib](https://github.com/gorkazl/pyGAlib), a Graph Analysis library in Python / Numpy. See module "*galib.extra*" at [https://github.com/gorkazl/pyGAlib/blob/master/galib/extra.py](https://github.com/gorkazl/pyGAlib/blob/master/galib/extra.py). 

#### Achieved impact
According to the records from the publisher's own records (The American Institute of Physics), the publication above is among the 10 most read articles of the journal CHAOS along 2017.

The model has served as the basis to define a generalised framework to describe the network-dynamic properties of weighted networks:
M. Gilson, **G. Zamora-López**, **N.E. Kouvaris**, and **G. Deco**, "*[Dynamic communicability and flow to describe complex network dynamics with linear feedback](https://arxiv.org/abs/1712.05693v1)*" arXiv:1712.05693v1 (2017).
The calculation of the Topological Similarity is one function in module 'galib.extra'

bb83c94a-8a3a-4830-95ae-2cc7905c7f5f.name: Recurrent neural networks that learn multi-step visual routines with reinforcement learning
bb83c94a-8a3a-4830-95ae-2cc7905c7f5f.description:
Many problems can be decomposed into series of subproblems that are solved sequentially. When the subproblems are solved, relevant intermediate results have to be stored and propagated from one subproblem to the next, until the overarching goal has been completed. The same applies for visual tasks that can be decomposed into sequences of elemental visual operations: experimental evidence suggests that for visual tasks, intermediate results are stored in working memory as an enhancement of neural activity in the visual cortex. The focus of enhanced activity is then available for subsequent subroutines to act upon. However, it remains unknown how those dynamics can emerge in neural networks that are trained with only rewards, as animals are.

Here, we propose a new recurrent architecture capable of solving composite visual tasks in a reinforcement learning context. We trained neural networks on three visual tasks for which electrophysiological recordings of monkeys’ visual cortex are available and updated weights following RELEARNN, a biologically plausible four-factor Hebbian learning rule, which is local both in time and space. The networks learned an abstract, general rule and selected the appropriate sequence of elemental operations, solely based on the characteristics of the visual stimuli and the reward structure.

The activity of the units of the neural network resembled the activity of neurons in the visual cortex of monkeys solving the same tasks. Relevant information that needed to be exchanged between subroutines was maintained as a focus of enhanced activity and passed on to the subsequent subroutines. Our results demonstrate how a biologically plausible learning rule can train a recurrent neural network on multistep visual tasks.

bd7b8352-0d30-40a4-b551-f8b4f93f65c5.name: Slow waves form expanding, memory-rich mesostates steered by local excitability in fading anesthesia
bd7b8352-0d30-40a4-b551-f8b4f93f65c5.description: In the arousal process from sleep and anesthesia, the brain restores its integrative and complex activity from the synchronized state of slow wave activity (SWA) characteristic of NREM sleep. The mechanisms and dynamics of the cortical network underpinning this state transition remain however to be elucidated. Here we investigated the progressive shaping of SWA propagating through the cortex on the way to wakefulness. Using micro-electrocorticographical recordings in the mouse, we pharmacologically increased levels of slow-wave frequency and complexity from deep unconsciousness toward wakefulness, and probed several single neuronal assemblies throughout the whole cortex. We found a form of memory in the SWA at deep anesthesia, with a tight alternation of posterior-anterior-posterior modes of slow-wave propagation. When approaching wakefulness, metastable patterns of spiking cortical activity propagated in many more directions, reflecting an increased complexity in the network dynamics. We unveil a temporal component of the dynamics of the waves’ mesostates, predicted by simulations of a model network of spiking neurons and confirmed in our experimental data. Local excitability suffices to explain the transition from sleep to wakefulness without requiring modifications of the network connectivity. These results shed new light on the functional re-organization of the cortical network in the awakening brain.

be001074-7eab-4c7e-9bde-9e5987b085d2.name: Multi-area model of macaque visual cortex
be001074-7eab-4c7e-9bde-9e5987b085d2.description:
This is a spiking model of all 32 vision-related areas of macaque cortex in the parcellation of Felleman and Van Essen (1991) implemented in NEST. Each area is modeled as a square mm microcircuit with the full density of neurons and synapses, leading to a total of 4 million neurons and 2.4 billion synapses. The neurons are modeled using the leaky integrate-and-fire model. Each microcircuit consists of layers 2/3, 4, 5, and 6 with an excitatory and inhibitory population each (except parahippocampal area TH, which lacks layer 4). All neurons receive independent Poisson spike trains as input. The cortico-cortical connectivity is based on a recent release of the CoCoMac database, quantitative tracing data (Markov et al., 2014), and predictive connectomics. The resulting connectivity matrix possesses a community structure that reflects functional groupings.

The model reproduces resting-state dynamics including area-level functional connectivity similar to that measured with fMRI, a spectrum of spiking activity and distribution of spike rates in V1 close to those from electrophysiological measurements (Chu et al. 2014), and propagation of activity across areas mainly in the feedback direction, aking to findings during visual imagery and sleep. The match with multi-scale experimental data occurs when the model is in a metastable state where multiple time scales of activity appear. The model enables layer-specific feedforward and feedback propagation between areas to be analyzed. The full model requires a high-performance cluster or supercomputer to be run, but a downscaling option is available.

The anatomical description of the model, including derivations of the population sizes and connectivity, is available in 
Schmidt M, Bakker R, Hilgetag CC, Diesmann M, van Albada SJ. *Multi-scale account of the network structure of macaque visual cortex* (2018) Brain Struct Func. 223(3):1409-1435. [https://doi.org/10.1007/s00429-017-1554-4](https://doi.org/10.1007/s00429-017-1554-4)

Slight adjustments to the connectivity are performed using a mean-field-based method that enforces the fundamental constraints of non-vanishing and non-saturated activity to be fulfilled. The theoretical method is published in 
Schuecker J, Schmidt M, van Albada SJ, Diesmann M, Helias M. *Fundamental activity constraints lead to specific interpretations of the connectome* (2017) PLoS CB 13(2):e1005179, [https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1005179](https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1005179)

The model dynamics is described in Schmidt M, Bakker R, Shen K, Bezgin G, Diesmann M, van Albada SJ. *A multi-scale layer-resolved spiking network model of resting-state dynamics in macaque visual cortical areas* (2018) PLOS CB 14:e1006359. [https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006359](https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006359)

Scienctists involved in this model:

Maximilian Schmidt, Sacha van Albada, Rembrandt Bakker, Jannis Schuecker, Alexander van Meegen, Jari Pronold, Markus Diesmann, Moritz Helias

For more information see https://inm-6.github.io/multi-area-model/

c0fb0b6f-5e91-49cb-9878-9d7a4900f130.name: Saccades for Scene Understanding Closed Loop
c0fb0b6f-5e91-49cb-9878-9d7a4900f130.description:
Human vision operates in light of physical constraints imposed by the eye as well as functional requirements such as having high visual acuity while maintaining a large field of view. Physically, the organization of the retina meets these constraints by densely packing photoreceptors within a small central region, the fovea, and letting photoreceptor density decrease rapidly towards the periphery. Functionally, this arrangement introduces a challenge for the visual system since only the region of external space fixated by the eyes is resolved with high acuity. To overcome this, vision involves information integration across samples of external space obtained by continuously repositioning the eyes. Co-design project 4 has developed a closed-loop architecture consisting of five functional modules:

    retinal image resampling
    object recognition
    saliency computation
    visual target selection
    saccade generation

and embodied this in a virtual iCub robot simulated on the neurorobotics platform.

c2688a43-75db-4b80-9404-0bfad78afc5f.name: Sudoku solver
c2688a43-75db-4b80-9404-0bfad78afc5f.description:
A solver for constraint satisfaction problems based on a network of spiking neurons with stochastic dynamics. The software is intended to run on the SpiNNaker neuromorphic hardware along with the sPyNNaker software package, the solver was developed with SpyNNaker7 so its use with later versions would require updating. The main source file is `spinnaker_csp/snn_creator.py`, the code on this file creates a network which connectivity encodes the constraint satisfaction problem, it also adds Poisson spike-sources to every population defining a possible value of a variable in the network. The constraints are encoded as inhibitory connections between such populations and the Poisson sources allow the network firing to relax in a configuration which violates the lesser constraints. Formally, this corresponds to a stochastic search over the state space defined by the problem variables and constraints, hence the solver inherits some advantage and disadvantage of stochastic searches. In particular, the solver is general in the sense of being applicable to any problem formulable as a set of variables with their respective domains and inequality constraints between those variables, but it does not solve all problems exactly and optimally, as well as is susceptible to local minima. The solver performance then depends on the problem complexity and its usefulness depends on whether the user desires always exact solutions or approximations are good. The repository includes an examples folder with scripts that use the solver to find solutions to the map-colouring, Sudoku puzzles and spin lattices problems.

See:

Fonseca Guerra GA and Furber SB (2017) Using Stochastic Spiking Neural Networks on SpiNNaker to Solve Constraint Satisfaction Problems. [https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnins.2017.00714/full] (https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnins.2017.00714/full)
Front. Neurosci. 11:714. [doi:10.3389/fnins.2017.00714](https://doi.org/10.3389/fnins.2017.00714)

c28c4e1f-0ef3-4ccd-9a81-8e792aa349a4.name: Model of two-photon calcium signals
c28c4e1f-0ef3-4ccd-9a81-8e792aa349a4.description:
This model aims to reproduce the fluorescence from single cells that is recorded in the two-photon experiments in anesthetized mice (Figure 1). To do so, we use a spiking network model of two populations of adaptive exponential integrate and fire neurons as a first step (see our model “2-populations spiking model of slow waves during anesthesia“). From the spikes and the membrane potential values simulated with this spiking network we model the two-photon signal of the cells (Figure 2). 


 ![Figure 1. Left, scheme of the two-photon experiments. Right, image acquired during two-photon recordings.](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_64bf8536ad8b4872a4121f909be7e82f/DestexheTeam/model-1324953f-0457-41ce-9c0e-b1bf997352b7-fig1-800px.png)

**Figure 1**. Left, scheme of the two-photon experiments. Right, image acquired during two-photon recordings.

 ![Figure 2. A, scheme of the two-population spiking network from which spike times and membrane voltage values are obtained. B. Conversion from spikes and membrane voltage to fluorescence with the calcium model. C. Activation of the voltage gated calcium channels.](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_64bf8536ad8b4872a4121f909be7e82f/DestexheTeam/model-1324953f-0457-41ce-9c0e-b1bf997352b7-fig2-800px.png)

**Figure 2.** A, scheme of the two-population spiking network from which spike times and membrane voltage values are obtained. B. Conversion from spikes and membrane voltage to fluorescence with the calcium model. C. Activation of the voltage gated calcium channels.

 ![Figure 3. Example of the simulated two-photon signals for 10 neurons of the excitatory (green) and the inhibitory population (red) corresponding to the realizations of the spiking network at different strengths of adaptation (raster plots on the top), which aim to reproduce the dynamics during the fading of anesthesia. The strength of adaptation in the spiking model (parameter b) takes the value of 50,30,10 and 3pA from left to right, respectively.](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_64bf8536ad8b4872a4121f909be7e82f/DestexheTeam/model-1324953f-0457-41ce-9c0e-b1bf997352b7-fig3-800px.png)

**Figure 3.** Example of the simulated two-photon signals for 10 neurons of the excitatory (green) and the inhibitory population (red) corresponding to the realizations of the spiking network at different strengths of adaptation (raster plots on the top), which aim to reproduce the dynamics during the fading of anesthesia. The strength of adaptation in the spiking model (parameter b) takes the value of 50,30,10 and 3pA from left to right, respectively.

**[Download detailed model description as PDF](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_64bf8536ad8b4872a4121f909be7e82f/DestexheTeam/collab_Model_2P_calcium_signals.pdf)**

This work is included in the article:

Allegra Mascaro AL, Falotico E, Petkoski S, Pasquini M, Vannucci L, Tort-Colet N, Conti E, Resta F, Spalletti C, Ramalingasetty ST, von Arnim A, Formento E, Angelidis E, Blixhavn CH, Leergaard TB, Caleo M, Destexhe A, Ijspeert A, Micera S, Laschi C, Jirsa V, Gewaltig M-O and Pavone FS (2020) Experimental and Computational Study on Motor Control and Recovery After Stroke: Toward a Constructive Loop Between Experimental and Virtual Embodied Neuroscience. *Front. Syst. Neurosci.* **14**:31. [doi:10.3389/fnsys.2020.00031](https://doi.org/10.3389/fnsys.2020.00031)

c3a4c662-ddab-41ff-99bf-4594edb0371c.name: Spiking network model of cortical areas exploring the edge of synchronization
c3a4c662-ddab-41ff-99bf-4594edb0371c.description:
Spiking network model of cortical areas exploring the edge of synchronization.
This model reproduces awake-like activity and,  if moved towards the critical point, experiences the emergence of sleep-like slow waves.

c50e0238-076d-41b4-9b64-9980d1f30994.name: Biophysical models of striatal neurons
c50e0238-076d-41b4-9b64-9980d1f30994.description:
Morphological and electrophysiological models of the striatal neurons: striatal projection neurons of the direct and indirect pathways (dSPN and iSPN, respectively), fast-spiking interneurons (FS), low threshold-spiking interneurons (LTS) and cholinergic interneurons (ChIN).

**SPN** Digital reconstructions of SPNs from the dorsal striatum of the mice were obtained from a  web-based inventory [NeuroMorpho.Org](http://neuromorpho.org/) (NMO). Reconstructions were assigned to dSPN (n=4) and iSPN (n=4) types based on their characteristic  morphometric features. Corrected morphologies for SPNs are available via [doi:10.25493/YP8N-HD2](http://doi.org/10.25493/YP8N-HD2). Experimental electrophysiological recordings are available via [doi:10.25493/MZE0-BH5](http://doi.org/10.25493/MZE0-BH5). [[Download models](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_c0a333ecf7c045809321ce9d9ecdfdea/Grillner_SGA2_T6.1.6/msn-model-2020Q1.zip)]

**FS** Morphological reconstruction of the striatal FS cells (n=3) were selected from a large pool of the cortical PV-expressing FS interneurons at NMO, repaired and validated against striatal FS morphometry, [doi:10.25493/3FNQ-5KG](http://doi.org/10.25493/3FNQ-5KG). Electrophysiological recordings are available via [doi:10.25493/E883-NFA](http://doi.org/10.25493/E883-NFA). [[Download models](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_c0a333ecf7c045809321ce9d9ecdfdea/Grillner_SGA2_T6.2.4/striatum-interneurons-model-2020Q1.zip)]

**LTS** The cells were filled with Neurobiotin during patch clamp recordings. The confocal z-stacks were used in a semi-manual reconstruction using Neutube and custom code. The most complete reconstruction (n=1) was selected for optimization, [doi:10.25493/DVPH-RDE](http://doi.org/10.25493/DVPH-RDE). Electrophysiological recordings are available via [doi:10.25493/5GE0-6MF](http://doi.org/10.25493/5GE0-6MF). [[Download model](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_c0a333ecf7c045809321ce9d9ecdfdea/Grillner_SGA2_T6.2.4/striatum/interneurons/optim/2020Q1/lts/str-lts-Experiment-9862_20181211.zip)]

**ChIN** The neurons were manually reconstructed (n=10; [doi:10.25493/3EV4-TDG](http://doi.org/10.25493/3EV4-TDG), [doi:10.25493/ADRK-VJP](http://doi.org/10.25493/ADRK-VJP)) using Neurolucida (MBF Bioscience) coupled to Zeiss Axio Imager.A1. The most complete reconstruction was selected for optimization. Model parameters are fitted to the experimental electrophysiological recordings, [doi:10.25493/3NTS-Q0B](http://doi.org/10.25493/3NTS-Q0B). [[Download model](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_c0a333ecf7c045809321ce9d9ecdfdea/Grillner_SGA2_T6.2.4/striatum/interneurons/optim/2020Q1/chin/str-chin-sbj4-170614_cell6-v20200221.zip)]

**Licence**: [Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA-4.0)](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/)

c64490c1-c8af-46c2-a0ea-ec489e7ba451.name: V1 cortical column model with multiple interneuron types
c64490c1-c8af-46c2-a0ea-ec489e7ba451.description:
We have built a a spiking network model of a cortical column, based on detailed electrophysiological and anatomical data of mouse V1, incorporating pyramidal cells, PV, SST and VIP inhibitory interneurons, and dynamics for AMPA, GABA and NMDA receptors.

The base model matches in vivo cell-type-specific firing rates for spontaneous and stimulus-evoked conditions in mice, but rhythmic activity is absent. Upon introduction of long-term synaptic plasticity, broad-band (15-60 Hz) oscillations emerge, with feedforward/feedback input streams enhancing/suppressing the oscillatory drive, respectively. These plasticity-triggered rhythms rely on all cell types, and specific experience-dependent connectivity patterns are required to generate oscillations.

Full instructions for running simulations, and reproducing figures from the associated paper, are given in the README file.
This is the first version of the model.

cb62b56e-bdfa-4016-81cd-c9dbc834cebc.name: Dendritic processing in hippocampal pyramidal cells - Kali & Freund, 2004
cb62b56e-bdfa-4016-81cd-c9dbc834cebc.description:
Area CA1 of the hippocampus contains a population of pyramidal cells, accompanied by a diverse array of inhibitory interneurons, which are believed to modulate the activity and plasticity of pyramidal neurons. 
This model creates detailed models of hippocampal principal cells and interneurons, which can be used to explore how these different cell types interact within the hippocampal network.

A model of CA1 pyramidal neurons, as described in:

S. Kali, T.F. Freund (2004) Dendritic processing in hippocampal pyramidal cells and its modulation by inhibitory interneurons. *Proceedings of the 2004 IEEE International Joint Conference on Neural Networks* [doi:10.1109/IJCNN.2004.1379985](http://doi.org/10.1109/IJCNN.2004.1379985)

cf46be9e-4a95-41d3-86a4-b61e2d5d4a09.name: Ball-and-stick network
cf46be9e-4a95-41d3-86a4-b61e2d5d4a09.description:
This model implements the rationale described in:

N. Fournier, E. Tanré, and R. Veltz. On a toy network of neurons interacting through their dendrites. **Annales de l'Institut Henri Poincaré (B) Probabilités et Statistiques**, 2019 

and 

T. Górski, R. Veltz, M. Galtier, H. Fragnaud, J. S. Goldman, B. Teleńczuk, and A. Destexhe. Dendritic sodium spikes endow neurons with inverse firing rate response to correlated synaptic activity **Journal of Computational Neuroscience**, 45(3), 2018.

In short, we provide a description of the annihilation of dendritic spikes and build a network of "Ball and Stick" spiking neurons.

cf769b89-e9a0-49e2-a393-2763481d89fc.name: Multimodal Predictive Coding Network with WhiskEye and the NRP (SGA-3 Showcase)
cf769b89-e9a0-49e2-a393-2763481d89fc.description:
A Multisensory Predictive Coding implementation designed to work with visual and tactile data from WhiskEye, either as a physical robot or a simulation on the Neurorobotics Platform. The goal is to produce useful internal representations of a complex environment that are suitable for place recognition and other navigation tasks.

## WhiskEye

WhiskEye\[1\] is a rat-inspired, biomimetic robot that explores its environment with a whisker array, cameras and other internal sensors. For the purposes of this model, it gathers visual, tactile and odometry data. The robot explores the world according to the features it finds most salient, enabling it to autonomously map the environment in a lifelike way, with learning algorithms, including implementations of predictive coding, building flexible representations of its surroundings in multiple modalities.

## MultiPredNet

The MultiPredNet draws on an implementation of predictive coding\[2\] and combines it with a multi-modal sensing architecture\[3\]. Built from a neural network upon the Tensorflow\[4\] framework, it is formed of several layers of bidirectional neurons, with a 'stack' of these layers corresponding to each distinct modality, or combination thereof. This particular example deals with visual and tactile data, and thus has three stacks: visual, tactile, and visuo-tactile.

Hypothesised causes of sensory inputs are passed down each stack towards the sensory input (back-to-front). Simultaneously, the input sensory signals subtract from these causes at each level, and the error fed back (front-to-back) to update the neural network.

## Place Recognition

The usefulness of the generated representations is analysed via examining an independent modality that the MultiPredNet had no knowledge of; the robot odometry. The assumption is made that a good, learned representation for place recognition will vary in a similar way to any other useful representation. In this case, pose space (x, y, $\theta$) is used as a reference.

Pose space itself should not be expected to directly relate to the robot's internal representation, especially considering the learning algorithm was not conditioned to recapitulate pose space as part of its loss function. However, given that pose space can unambiguously represent 2D position and orientation - a requirement also given of any useful learned representation - it is expected that a learned representation will vary *in the same way* as pose space.

## Representational Similarity Analysis

Representational Similarity Analysis\[5\] allows for a robust metric of how fit for purpose this learned representation is. Such a determination is given by the Representational Similarity Matrix, a within-representation comparison of how similar instances within that representation are. Comparing the Matrices of different representations given the same visuo-tactile input, should, in a good metric, show that the two representations co-vary to a large degree. The exact degree of co-variance is given by the Spearman's Rank Correlation Coefficient; this is then used as a metric of how useful the learned representation is.

## References

\[1\] O. Struckmeier, K. Tiwari, M. Pearson, and V. Kyrki, “Vita-slam: A bio-inspired visuo-tactileslam for navigation while interacting with aliased environments,” Jun. 2019.

\[2\]  S. Dora, C. Pennartz, S. Bohte, *A  Deep  Predictive  Coding  Network  for  Inferring  Hierarchical  Causes  Underlying  Sensory  Inputs*,  International  Conference  on  Artificial  NeuralNetworks,  Springer,  Cham,  2018. 
Available: https://pure.ulster.ac.uk/ws/files/77756390/ICANN_submission.pdf

\[3\] O.  Struckmeier,  K.  Tiwari,  S.  Dora,  M.  J.  Pearson,  S.  M.  Bohte,  C.  M.  Pennartz,  and  V.Kyrki, *Mupnet:  Multi-modal  predictive  coding  network  for  place  recognition  by  unsupervised learning of joint visuo-tactile latent representations*, 2019. arXiv:1909.07201

\[4\] M. Abadi et al.  *TensorFlow:  Large-scale  machine  learning  on  heterogeneous  systems*. Available: https://www.tensorflow.org/

\[5\] N Kriegeskorte, M Mur, and P. Bandettini. Front. Syst. Neurosci., 24 November 2008 | https://doi.org/10.3389/neuro.06.004.2008
Now with working dataset link

d191597a-bb56-497e-acc2-5cdd5c564b73.name: Purkinje cell model, generic version - Masoli et al., 2015
d191597a-bb56-497e-acc2-5cdd5c564b73.description: Masoli et al. 2015 model of PurkinjeCell (PC) and published in 10.3389/fncel.2015.00047 This is general PC model unlike special Z+ or Z- models. The model is based on adult (P90 or 3 months) Guinea pig. PC in younger ones are not mature and they grow until P90. This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model in modelDB accession 229585. Code to Model template for PC2015Masoli This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model for CerebUnit. To run this model: from executive import ExecutiveControl as ec desired_model = ec.choose_model( modelscale = "cells", modelname = "PC2015Masoli" ) Model description in ModelDB #229585 The Purkinje cell is one of the most complex type of neuron in the central nervous system and is well known for its massive dendritic tree. The initiation of the action potential was theorized to be due to the high calcium channels presence in the dendritic tree but, in the last years, this idea was revised. In fact, the Axon Initial Segment, the first section of the axon was seen to be critical for the spontaneous generation of action potentials. The model reproduces the behaviours linked to the presence of this fundamental sections and the interplay with the other parts of the neuron. Note: Cavia porcellus (Guinea pig) under species when it becomes available. This is a multi-compartment model such that self.regions = {"soma": ["v"], "dend": ["v"], "axonAIS": ["v"], "axonNOR": ["v"], "axonNOR2": ["v"], "axonNOR3": ["v"]} self.recordingunits = {"v": "mV"}

d1c1388a-2331-4b7d-8bb8-cdfbc7a0acd3.name: Human Purkinje cell model (Masoli et al., 2024)
d1c1388a-2331-4b7d-8bb8-cdfbc7a0acd3.description:
[[From ModelDB](https://modeldb.science/267694)]

A morphologically and biophysically-detailed model of a human Purkinje cell, 
based on high-resolution morphological reconstructions and unique electrophysiological recordings of human Purkinje cells *ex vivo*.

A version of this model for a [mouse Purkinje cell](https://search.kg.ebrains.eu/live/6dc46db1-6fc6-4ca0-8cec-55ac499c4b5d) is also available.

### Requirements

- The model was implemented in Python 3 and NEURON 8.
- NEURON 8.2.2 runs the model without issues but the model does not run on NEURON 9, yet.

The model uses NEURON multisplit to distribute automatically the calculation on all the available cores (up to 32 cores).

### Usage instructions

- Download and extract the archive.
- Change directory to `human_model`. 
- Run `nrnivmodl ./mod_files` to compile the mod files.
- To switch between no spine and spine there is a variable in each protocol except for the protocols 03, 05 and 06.
- Run `nrngui -python ./protocols/0x_protocol` with `0x_protocol` the name of the Python file in the protocols directory. 

The model is provided with seven protocols able to reproduce:

- 01 - spontaneous firing
- 02 - Positive current injections
- 03 - Ramp current injection

The number of synapses, types, bursts frequency can be set in the dictionary at the start of the protocol.

- 04 - Random synaptic locations - burst/pause
- 05 - Fixed synaptic locations - burst/pause
- 06 - Spine fixed location - burst/pause

### Note

The model does not work with the variable time step. Not tested under NEURON for windows or Mac OS.
This is the first release on ModelDB.

d202689d-8180-401a-8004-cc9ee5484db0.name: CEREBRUM-7T: a convolutional neural network model for segmentation of 7 tesla MRI brain volumes
d202689d-8180-401a-8004-cc9ee5484db0.description: Ultra high-field MRI enables sub-millimetre resolution imaging of the human brain, allowing the study of functional circuits of cortical layers at the meso-scale. An essential step in many functional and structural neuroimaging studies is segmentation, the operation of partitioning the MR images in anatomical structures. Despite recent efforts in brain imaging analysis, the literature lacks in accurate and fast methods for segmenting 7 Tesla (7T) brain MRI. We here present CEREBRUM-7T, an optimised end-to-end Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), that allows fully automatic segmentation of a whole 7T T1w MRI brain volume at once, without partitioning the volume, preprocessing, nor aligning it to an atlas. The trained model is able to produce accurate multi-structure segmentation masks on six different classes plus background in only a few seconds. To learn how to use CEREBRUM-7T from source code, docker, or singularity, please visit [https://rocknroll87q.github.io/cerebrum7t/usage](https://rocknroll87q.github.io/cerebrum7t/usage). First public release

d2d8cb31-de91-42fe-8472-4ac0bb7e444d.name: CA1 Human hippocampus network for single point neuron simulations
d2d8cb31-de91-42fe-8472-4ac0bb7e444d.description:
This is a full-scale scaffold model of the human hippocampus CA1 area, based on data obtained from the analysis of histological human brain images, which are publicly available from the BigBrain Jülich repository. A custom-made computational algorithm has been developed to extract from the images the positions of neuronal somata.

A second custom made algorithm has been developed to connect neurons following morpho-anatomical landmarks. The full matrix of neuronal positioning together with the indices of connected neurons is provided as a connection matrix in order to be used for large-scale simulation with single point neurons.


The data are organized as follows:

1. The Neuronal placement text file `HUMAN_PLACEMENT_4_8M_Pyr.txt` allows generating the complete human CA1 scaffold. It contains 4 columns containing the 3D coordinates and the GID (Global Index) of pyramidal cells and interneurons of the human CA1 hippocampus obtained from the image analysis of the histological sections of a full brain downloaded from the BigBrain repository.
2. The connectivity matrices in the hdf5 files allow to generate the full matrix of connection pairs. Each dataset in the hdf5 files contains a set of 2-column arrays with the pairs of numbers indicating the GID of presynaptic and postsynaptic neurons connected with the developed algorithm.
3. The two directories `long_simdata_human_01ffa4a7-a809-43f5-83c1-5cc839a1dc52_only_exc_connections/` and `long_simdata_human_5f859adf-469c-4f37-89e6-9d2e13f776da_inh_movie_paper/` contain data generated by running simulations with either only the excitatory connections or both the excitatory and inhibitory connections, to allow the inspection of simulation results without having to run the simulations.

## Instructions to run the model.

The scripts to run the simulation are in the `hippocampus_human_collab` directory. Running the model currently requires an account on Piz Daint at [CSCS](https://https://www.cscs.ch).
The model is made to run on NEST. NEST is available in a Docker image that has to be loaded using Sarus on Piz Daint. The script `sarus_load_image.sh` takes care of loading the Docker image `showcase_2.tar` on Sarus. The authors thank Lionel Kusch (Aix Marseille University) for the technical assistance in compiling the NEST simulator in a Docker image.

To run the model:

- Download the following files and directories:
    * `hippocampus_human_collab/placement_connections_scaffold.hdf5` (80 GB!!!)
    * `inh_remapped/` (39 GB).
- Copy the files `helper.py`, `synaptic_models.py`, `neuron_models.py` from  `"long_simdata_human_01ffa4a7-a809-43f5-83c1-5cc839a1dc52_only_exc_connections/"` to `"hippocampus_human_collab/"`.
- Set the correct path `"input_hdf5_data_dir"` in the beginning of the `run_nest_serialized_connect.py` script to point to the location of the 
`placement_connections_scaffold.hdf5`
- Set the correct account for HPC resources in `run_sarus_normal.sh`.
- Run by executing the bash script: `Start_Human_Hippocampus.sh`

The script will create a directory in your $SCRATCH dir and store the simulation data.

Before running consider that a single simulation takes up to 3 hours to complete and uses 2400 CPU hours from your HPC account.

For support contact Sergio Solinas.

d342fa8a-9bfe-4a94-9579-ec641c485039.name: Mouse CA1 pyramidal neuron model, morphology mpg150223_B1_idB
d342fa8a-9bfe-4a94-9579-ec641c485039.description:
This model is part of a collection of ten distinct single-cell computational models of mouse CA1 pyramidal neurons, created using a well-established computational workflow, and ready to be used in a full-scale hippocampal circuit. This data-driven model is based on a 3D reconstruction of a biocytin-stained cell morphology using Neurolucida and on electrophysiological features extracted from data collected from mice by patch-clamp, and implemented using the BluePyOpt algorithm.
This version of the model is the one used in Vitale et al. (2023) [doi:10.3389/fncel.2023.1281932](https://doi.org/10.3389/fncel.2023.1281932)

d42fcb8e-8dc0-4196-9773-7bf9fc134c67.name: Kinetic scheme of inhibitory events including gephyrin
d42fcb8e-8dc0-4196-9773-7bf9fc134c67.description:
Computational modeling of brain circuits requires the definition of many parameters that are difficult to determine from experimental findings. One way to help interpret these data is to fit them using a particular kinetic model. The classic and widely used bi-exponential synaptic conductance change does not capture well the resulting variabilities of the IPSCs. Most importantly, however, it cannot give much information on the subcellular pathways underlying synaptic transmission. A relatively basic model for gephyrin was implemented. 
 
There are three main reasons for this choice:  

1. it is one of the major players for synaptic transmission, and of particular importance in inhibitory synapses  

2. we were able to implement a specific kinetic model simple enough to be, at the same time, informative and analytically solvable, and  

3. we plan to carry out soon (for a future paper) experiments using a new type of antibody to selectively block Gephyrin ex vivo, to compare experimental data with the model's prediction.  


For a more detailed description of the model see Lupascu CA, Morabito A, Merenda E, et al. A General Procedure to Study Subcellular Models of Transsynaptic Signaling at Inhibitory Synapses. Frontiers in Neuroinformatics. 2016;10:23. [doi:10.3389/fninf.2016.00023](https://doi.org/10.3389/fninf.2016.00023).

![Kinetic Scheme](https://object.cscs.ch/v1/AUTH_c0a333ecf7c045809321ce9d9ecdfdea/sp6_usecase_resources/figures/Gephyrin-kinetic-scheme.jpg)

d4b96997-43fe-44ee-a1ce-fe15226e6c1a.name: Mouse CA1 pyramidal neuron model, morphology mpg150304_A2_idA
d4b96997-43fe-44ee-a1ce-fe15226e6c1a.description:
This model is part of a collection of ten distinct single-cell computational models of mouse CA1 pyramidal neurons, created using a well-established computational workflow, and ready to be used in a full-scale hippocampal circuit. This data-driven model is based on a 3D reconstruction of a biocytin-stained cell morphology using Neurolucida and on electrophysiological features extracted from data collected from mice by patch-clamp, and implemented using the BluePyOpt algorithm.
This version of the model is the one used in Vitale et al. (2023) [doi:10.3389/fncel.2023.1281932](https://doi.org/10.3389/fncel.2023.1281932)

d53292bd-90cb-4049-8837-1e6e19b3f0fe.name: Model of timing dependent reward plasticity - SGA1-T6.1.2
d53292bd-90cb-4049-8837-1e6e19b3f0fe.description: In reward learning, the integration of NMDA-dependent calcium and dopamine by striatal projection neurons leads to potentiation of corticostriatal synapses through CaMKII/PP1 signaling. In order to elicit the CaMKII/PP1-dependent response, the calcium and dopamine inputs should arrive in temporal proximity and must follow a specific (dopamine after calcium) order. In this computational study, we propose that these temporal requirements emerge as a result of the coordinated signaling via two striatal phosphoproteins, DARPP-32 and ARPP-21. Model published 2016; doi: 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1005080

d6f1736e-b84d-4a2f-aeb8-75930ff5eba1.name: Spatial and Episodic Memory
d6f1736e-b84d-4a2f-aeb8-75930ff5eba1.description:
Based on previous work on human episodic memory (the so-called Byrne, Becker and Burgess-model; Byrne et al. 2008) we have built a model of how neural representations of egocentric spatial experiences in the parietal lobe interface with viewpoint-independent representations in medial temporal lobe, to enable many key aspects of spatial cognition. The model shows how specific, experimentally characterised, neural responses (place cells, head-direction cells, boundary- and object-vector cells, grid cells, and parietal gain-field neurons) map onto higher cognitive function in a modular way. The interactions between these populations of neurons across multiple brain regions provide a mechanistic account of spatial memory, scene construction, novelty-detection, and mental navigation. In particular the model shows how so-called object vector cells (OVCs) may allow memory for items to be incorporated into a contextual representation based on extended environmental boundaries (as expressed in the firing of boundary vector cells; or BVCs). The same cells provide the neural correlate of objects in context during recall/visuospatial imagery (cf. Figure). Simulations have been implemented in MatLab (using rate coded neurons).

Bicanski A, Burgess N. A neural-level model of spatial memory and imagery. ELife. 2018 Sep 4;7:e33752.

Byrne P, Becker S, Burgess N. Remembering the past and imagining the future: a neural model of spatial memory and imagery. Psychological review. 2007 Apr;114(2):340.

Code location: https://github.com/bicanski/HBPcollab

d72236bd-6831-417a-8846-8ee28dc66e9b.name: Modeling mesoscopic cortical dynamics using a mean-field model of conductance-based networks of adaptive exponential integrate-and-fire neurons
d72236bd-6831-417a-8846-8ee28dc66e9b.description:
Voltage-sensitive dye imaging (VSDi) has revealed fundamental properties of neocortical processing at macroscopic scales. Since for each pixel VSDi signals report the average membrane potential over hundreds of neurons, it seems natural to use a mean-field formalism to model such signals. Here, we present a mean-field model of networks of Adaptive Exponential (AdEx) integrate-and-fire neurons, with conductance-based synaptic interactions. We study a network of regular-spiking (RS) excitatory neurons and fast-spiking (FS) inhibitory neurons. We use a Master Equation formalism, together with a semi-analytic approach to the transfer function of AdEx neurons to describe the average dynamics of the coupled populations. We compare the predictions of this mean-field model to simulated networks of RS-FS cells, first at the level of the spontaneous activity of the network, which is well predicted by the analytical description. Second, we investigate the response of the network to time-varying external input, and show that the mean-field model predicts the response time course of the population. Finally, to model VSDi signals, we consider a one-dimensional ring model made of interconnected RS-FS mean-field units. We found that this model can reproduce the spatio-temporal patterns seen in VSDi of awake monkey visual cortex as a response to local and transient visual stimuli. Conversely, we show that the model allows one to infer physiological parameters from the experimentally-recorded spatio-temporal patterns.
This implementation provides the code to run three types of numerical simulations. 

1. A local network model (typically 5000 neurons,  implementation based on Brian2) of sparsely connected AdExp neurons (RS and FS types), 
2. the mean-field equations describing the evolution of the population activity of this biophysical model, 3. a mesoscopic model describing a ~5mm area of the cortex, based on the interconnections of the local mean-field model.

dae51b52-2229-446c-bb48-8176e2e66e7d.name: Granule cell 2019 - Accelerating
dae51b52-2229-446c-bb48-8176e2e66e7d.description:
Granule Cell 2019 - Accelerating model. The model will show an incresing in action potential generation after 1600ms of simulations.

To correctly simulate it: 
1) Temperature = 32°
2) Vinit (Vm) = -70
3) Currents injection used in the paper = 10, 16 and 22pA
4) Currents injection, 100ms delay, 2000ms injection and 2000ms tstop (length of the simulation)
Parameter tuning differentiates granule cell subtypes enriching the repertoire of retransmission properties at the cerebellum input stage.
Stefano Masoli, Marialuisa Tognolina, Umberto Laforenza, Francesco Moccia, Egidio D’Angelo
bioRxiv 638247; doi: https://doi.org/10.1101/638247

e02c0163-3c3c-45bc-a1af-5a29df859dcf.name: Hippocampal & Striatal navigation
e02c0163-3c3c-45bc-a1af-5a29df859dcf.description:
Behavioural and neural data suggest that multiple strategies and brain systems support learning about reward. Reinforcement learning (RL) considers these strategies in terms of model-based (MB) learning, which involves learning an explicit transition model of the available state-space, or model-free (MF) learning, which involves directly estimating the cumulative future reward associated with each state. The MB-MF distinction parallels that between place learning and response learning within spatial navigation. Lesion and inactivation studies suggests that dorsal hippocampus (dHC) underlies both MB and place learning, whereas dorsolateral striatum (DLS) underlies MF and response learning. Here, we present a computational model of the dHC and DLS contributions to reward learning that applies to spatial and nonspatial domains. In the model, hippocampal place cell firing reflects the geodesic distance of other states from its preferred state along the graph of task structure. Accordingly, this population can support a value function or goal cell firing rate, via one-shot learning, on which gradient ascent corresponds to taking the shortest path on the graph, behaviour associated with MB planning. In contrast, the DLS learns through MF stimulus-response associations with egocentric environmental cues. We show that this model reproduces animal behaviour on spatial navigation tasks using the Morris Water Maze and the Plus Maze, and human behaviour on non-spatial two-step decision tasks. We discuss how the geodesic place cell fields could be learnt, and how this type of representation helps to span the gap between MB and MF learning. The generality of our model, originally shaped by detailed constraints in the spatial literature, suggests that the hippocampal-striatal system is a general-purpose learning device that adaptively combines MB and MF mechanisms.  

[Detailed description of simulations and results](https://github.com/bicanski/HBPcollab/blob/master/Striatal_v_hippocampal_nav_v2/Modelling_hippocampal_and_dorsolateral_striatal_contributions_to_learning_across_domains.pdf)

e1080dd2-75fb-4077-be15-0e06d2eb1fbf.name: A biologically plausible gated recurrent neural network for working memory and learning-to-learn
e1080dd2-75fb-4077-be15-0e06d2eb1fbf.description:
This is an implementation of RECOLLECT, a computational architecture that can learn to attend to relevant information and store it in working memory using a biologically plausible learning rule.

For more details see:

A.R. van den Berg, P. R. Roelfsema & S. M. Bohte (2023). Biologically plausible gated recurrent neural networks for working memory and learning-to-learn.[doi:10.1101/2023.07.06.547911v1](https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.07.06.547911v1) Biorxiv.

## Dependencies
* Python (tested on 3.8.0)
* Numpy (tested on 1.23.1)
* Pandas (tested on 1.2.3)
* Matplotlib (tested on 3.3.4, but not required to run the code)

## Using RECOLLECT
An example of how to use RECOLLECT has been provided for the pro-/anti-saccade task from Gottlieb and Goldberg (1999).

e291f64c-a7e6-4858-ba5a-9f8fd2bc8ae9.name: Thalamo-cortical spiking model with sleep-like slow oscillations improving awake visual classification through synaptic homeostasis and memory association
e291f64c-a7e6-4858-ba5a-9f8fd2bc8ae9.description:
The occurrence of sleep passed through the evolutionary sieve and is widespread in animal species. Sleep is known to be beneficial to cognitive and mnemonic tasks, while chronic sleep deprivation is detrimental. Despite the importance of the phenomenon, a complete understanding of its functions and underlying mechanisms is still lacking. 
In this simplified thalamo-cortical model, trained to encode, retrieve and classify images of handwritten digits, we show interesting effects of deep-sleep-like slow oscillation activity. During slow oscillations, spike-timing-dependent-plasticity (STDP) produces a differential homeostatic process. It is characterized by both a specific unsupervised enhancement of connections among groups of neurons associated to instances of the same class (digit) and a simultaneous down-regulation of stronger synapses created by the training. This hierarchical organization of post-sleep internal representations favours higher performances in retrieval and classification tasks. The mechanism is based on the interaction between top-down cortico-thalamic predictions and bottom-up thalamo-cortical projections during deep-sleep-like slow oscillations. Indeed, when learned patterns are replayed during sleep, cortico-thalamo-cortical connections favour the activation of other neurons coding for similar thalamic inputs, promoting their association. Such mechanism hints at possible applications to artificial learning systems.

Reference
Cristiano Capone, Elena Pastorelli, Bruno Golosio, Pier Stanislao Paolucci. Sleep-like slow oscillations improve visual classification through synaptic homeostasis and memory association in a thalamo-cortical model. Sci Rep 9, 8990 (2019) doi:10.1038/s41598-019-45525-0

e65af953-95bd-4b3b-b227-8895cff1e653.name: A theoretical formalization of consequence-based decision-making
e65af953-95bd-4b3b-b227-8895cff1e653.description:
Learning to make adaptive decisions depends on exploring options, experiencing their consequence, and reassessing one’s strategy for the future. Although several studies have analyzed various aspects of value-based decision-making, most of them have focused on decisions in which gratification is cued and immediate. By contrast, how the brain gauges delayed consequence for decision-making remains poorly understood.

To investigate this, we designed a novel decision-making task in which each decision altered future options to decide upon. The task was organized in groups of inter-dependent trials, and the participants were instructed to maximize cumulative reward value within each group. In the absence of any explicit performance feedback, the participants had to test and internally assess specific criteria to make decisions. The absence of explicit feedback was key to specifically study how the assessment of consequence forms and influences decisions as learning progresses.

We formalized this operation mathematically by means of a multi-layered decision-making model. It uses a mean-field approximation to describe the dynamics of two populations of neurons which characterize the binary decision-making process. The resulting decision-making policy is dynamically modulated by an internal oversight mechanism based on the prediction of consequence. This policy is reinforced by rewarding outcomes. The model was validated by fitting each individual participants’ behavior. It faithfully predicted non-trivial patterns of decision-making, regardless of performance level.

These findings provide an explanation to how delayed consequence may be computed and incorporated into the neural dynamics of decision-making, and to how adaptation occurs in the absence of explicit feedback.

To run the model, download the code from the GitHub link, and save it in your computer. Open MATLAB, set the current folder to the one where you saved the files, and run the main script called `script_main.m`. Follow the instructions displayed in the command window.
This is the first public release of the model.

e81bc325-8027-4f13-8419-34990a08fc3c.name: Model-based spatial navigation in the hippocampus - ventral striatum circuit
e81bc325-8027-4f13-8419-34990a08fc3c.description:
The computational model explores the links between model-based reinforcement learning (MB-RL) and the functioning of the hippocampus (HC) and the ventral striatum (vStr):  a neuronal circuit that is increasingly recognized as an appropriate model system to understand goal-directed (spatial) decisions and planning mechanisms in the brain. 

We tested the MB-RL agent in a contextual conditioning task that depends on intact hippocampus and ventral striatal (shell) function and show that it solves the task while showing key behavioral and neuronal signatures of the HC—vStr circuit. Our simulations also explore the benefits of biological forms of look-ahead prediction (forward sweeps) during both learning and control. This model thus contributes to fill the gap between our current understanding of computational algorithms and biological realizations of (model-based) reinforcement learning.

The model is fully described in "Stoianov IP, Pennartz CMA, Lansink CS, Pezzulo G (2018) Model-based spatial navigation in the hippocampus-ventral striatum circuit: A computational analysis. PLoS Comput Biol 14(9): e1006316. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006316"

Note that the model has been also implemented in the Neurorobotics platform:
https://collab.humanbrainproject.eu/#/collab/78682/nav/532632

e919d175-b831-4295-b84c-9b00c944f0e3.name: Olfactory bulb network model - Davison, Feng & Brown (2003)
e919d175-b831-4295-b84c-9b00c944f0e3.description:
A biologically-detailed model of the mammalian olfactory bulb, incorporating the mitral and granule cells and the dendrodendritic synapses between them. The results of simulation experiments with electrical stimulation agree closely in most details with published experimental data. The model predicts that the time course of dendrodendritic inhibition is dependent on the network connectivity as well as on the intrinsic parameters of the synapses. In response to simulated odor stimulation, strongly activated mitral cells tend to suppress neighboring cells, the mitral cells readily synchronize their firing, and increasing the stimulus intensity increases the degree of synchronization.

A full description may be found in:
Davison A.P., Feng J. and Brown D. (2003) Dendrodendritic
inhibition and simulated odor responses in a detailed
olfactory bulb network model. *J. Neurophysiol.* 90:1921-35

For more information, contact andrew.davison@cnrs.fr
This version was created for the [ReScience Reproducibility Challenge 2020](http://rescience.github.io/ten-years/).

The original code version posted on ModelDB provided the model together with code to reproduce two of the figures from the original article.

This version provides code to reproduce *all of the figures* from the original article.

**How to use this code**

To reproduce the figures from this paper, install NEURON, change to the code directory, run:

```
  $ nrnivmodl
```

then for each figure run:

```
  $ python run.py figure_2
```

and similarly for the other figures.

**Dependencies**

- NEURON (https://neuron.yale.edu/neuron/)
- Gnuplot (http://www.gnuplot.info/)
- Python (v3.6 or more recent)
- NumPy
- PyYAML
- Jinja2
- epstopdf (optional - for converting figure to PDF)
- ImageMagick (optional - for converting figures to PNG)

ec58052d-a4d0-4e2a-bd20-c0053e0cd873.name: A model of presynaptic Kv7 channel function in hippocampal mossy fiber boutons - Martinello et al. 2019
ec58052d-a4d0-4e2a-bd20-c0053e0cd873.description:
In hippocampus, a type of slowly-activated and non-inactivating K+ channels, belonging to the Kv7 family, are highly localized on initial segments of myelinated and unmyelinated axons where they influence neuronal excitability. Interestingly, immunohistochemistry shows that the KV7.2 and KV7.3 subunits are localized throughout hippocampal mossy fibers. Electrophysiological recordings from mature synaptic boutons showed that the KV7/M- current is also present here, is active at rest and enhances the membrane conductance. The current also reduces the spike half-width and afterdepolatization (ADP) following a presynaptic spike. This is likely to have significant consequences for the modulation of excitatory neurotransmitter release from these boutons, and thus signal transmission, at DG-CA3 synapses. We implemented a biophysical computational model of a mossy fiber bouton (MFB) in order to highlight the mechanisms underlying the ADP observed after Kv7 channels block. The model is able to reproduce a number of experimental findings under control and after Kv7 current block by XE991. The results suggest that Kv7 conductance limits spike-induced rise in Ca2+ concentration and regulates spike width and ADP amplitude. The model suggests that the ADP is caused by a relatively slow Ca2+-dependent mechanism, which can be conveniently modelled as a slow deactivation time constant of the Ca2+ current in MFB. This is a new feature that has not been previously observed experimentally. Taken together, these results suggest that presynaptic Kv7 channels expression at the mossy fiber-CA3 synapse may have an important role in modulating synaptic transmission and signal coding in the hippocampus network.

For a more detailed description of the model see:

Martinello, K., Giacalone, E., Migliore, M., Brown, D. A., & Shah, M. M. (2019). The subthreshold-active KV7 current regulates neurotransmission by limiting spike-induced Ca2+ influx in hippocampal mossy fiber synaptic terminals. *Communications biology*, **2**, 145. [doi:10.1038/s42003-019-0408-4](https://doi.org/10.1038/s42003-019-0408-4)

ecf6f9e2-7bfb-4654-80af-e6d66e8ff700.name: Multiarea Hill-Tononi thalamocortical network model
ecf6f9e2-7bfb-4654-80af-e6d66e8ff700.description: A thalamocortical network model using hybrid conductance-based/IAF neurons to investigate measures and mechanisms of consciousness.

f1c9dd6f-0efe-43db-9d73-9a0f7a2faf9a.name: Purkinje cell 2009 for studying effect of voltage sensitive fluorescent proteins on excitability (PC2009Akemann)
f1c9dd6f-0efe-43db-9d73-9a0f7a2faf9a.description:
Akemann et al 2009 model of PurkinjeCell (PC) and published in 10.1016/j.bpj.2009.02.046 This is a single compartment model. It is a modified version of their 2006 PC model. This one has recombinant proteins VSFP2.3 and VSFP3.1. This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model in modelDB accession 123453. Code to Model template for PC2009Akemann This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model for CerebUnit. To run this model: from executive import ExecutiveControl as ec desired_model = ec.choose_model( modelscale = "cells", modelname = "PC2009Akemann" ) Model description in ModelDB #123453 Fluorescent protein voltage sensors are recombinant proteins that are designed as genetically encoded cellular probes of membrane potential using mechanisms of voltage-dependent modulation of fluorescence. Several such proteins, including VSFP2.3 and VSFP3.1, were recently reported with reliable function in mammalian cells. ... Expression of these proteins in cell membranes is accompanied by additional dynamic membrane capacitance, ... We used recordings of sensing currents and fluorescence responses of VSFP2.3 and of VSFP3.1 to derive kinetic models of the voltage-dependent signaling of these proteins. Using computational neuron simulations, we quantitatively investigated the perturbing effects of sensing capacitance on the input/output relationship in two central neuron models, a cerebellar Purkinje and a layer 5 pyramidal neuron. Note: PC2009Akemann is not the same as PC2006Akemann because:
  1. At high depolarizing potentials (>−20 mV) Purkinje neurons show strong outward rectification caused by a high expression of Kv3.3 and, at lower levels, Kv3.4 channel units in the somatic and dendritic membrane. In the original model Kv3 channels were implemented by a generic model, termed bKv3, with step-like activation and deactivation. For this study the bKv3 model was replaced by a Hodgkin-Huxley mechanism with m = 4 derived from a least-square fit to recent experimental data of Martina et al. The resulting rate coefficients at 22°C are αn(V) = 0.22/ms × exp[(V + 16 mV)/26.5 mV] and βn(V) = 0.22/ms × exp[−(V + 16 mV)/26.5 mV]. This model reaches half activation at +6 mV (steady-state) with a time constant (at 22°C) of 1.5 ms at +10 mV and 0.7 ms at +30 mV.
  2. The original model was developed with the idea to reproduce the physiological effects resulting from the existence of Na+ ion channels with resurgent (Nav1.6) and nonresurgent (Nav1.1 and Nav1.2) kinetics in Purkinje neurons. In this study we simplified the Na+ kinetics by omitting the Nav1.6 channel and increasing the density of the Nav1.1/1.2 channel from 14 to 38 mS/cm2.
  3. To elevate the kinetics of all channels to be consistent with a temperature of 37°C, as used in this study, rate coefficients were temperature-corrected using a q10 of 2.7.
  4. Gating currents were calculated using Eq. 3 with parameters specified as (g, m, zn, zh): Nav1.1/1.2 (15 pS, 4, 2.54, 0), Kv1 (16 pS, 4, 2.80, 0), Kv3 (16 pS, 4, 1.92, 0), Kv4 (16 pS, 4, 1.47, −5.47), KCa1.1(BK) (182 pS, 3, 4.10, −4.38), Cav2.1(P-type) (10 pS, 1, 4.62, 0), HCN1(Ih) (0.68 pS, 1, −2.57, 0). Values of gating valences were derived from the rate constant expressions of each channel. Unitary conductances were taken from single-channel recording data as found in the literature.
This model is the SciUnit wrapped version of the NEURON model.

f3fa3710-5b91-4b8f-a25b-da4a35e7f73d.name: Mouse CA1 pyramidal neuron model, morphology mpg150217_A2_idA
f3fa3710-5b91-4b8f-a25b-da4a35e7f73d.description:
This model is part of a collection of ten distinct single-cell computational models of mouse CA1 pyramidal neurons, created using a well-established computational workflow, and ready to be used in a full-scale hippocampal circuit. This data-driven model is based on a 3D reconstruction of a biocytin-stained cell morphology using Neurolucida and on electrophysiological features extracted from data collected from mice by patch-clamp, and implemented using the BluePyOpt algorithm.
This version of the model is the one used in Vitale et al. (2023) [doi:10.3389/fncel.2023.1281932](https://doi.org/10.3389/fncel.2023.1281932)
